We ordered the egg rolls, beef pho, and the bun bo hue. All was tasty, but I wished the broths came out hotter. It was a chilly Saturday and the broths cooled fairly quickly. Overall, the flavors were all spot-on and it was a tasty lunch. The hubs was also mighty impressed with the cleanliness of their condiments, which he found very pleasing. They're cash only too.
author: Lisa R.

description: The best choice in the whole city for early morning (8am) pho: a delicious breakfast for those into savory tastes.
author: David S.

description:
DO NOT EAT HERE.

I witnessed an employee here violently assaulting a homeless woman. Instead of handling an issue properly and escalating to the police he beat up a homeless woman begging for change and food. I watched an employee her thrown a woman to the ground, drag her by the hair and completely without remorse. 

DO NOT SUPPORT THIS BUSINESS
author: Eric S.

description:
The best cure to a hang over.  The broth was good and flavorful and they don't skimp on the noodles/meat/broth.  It's in the TL but not too far from Union Square, so you can eat quick style then gtfo.  We got plain pho and #23, which has brisket in size medium and large.  Sounds like we're talking t-shirts, but if you're going to get the large, come prepared with a big appetite.  

Cash only.
author: Eunice J.

description:
Ever since I found Golden Star, I've been hesitant about getting pho anywhere else, because, well, they're pretty damn good. So, when my friend suggested that we all meet up here, I showed up with a bit of skepticism, that dissipated pretty quickly once I got my #8 pho.

Great, flavorful broth, tasty noodles, and very generous portions. In fact, I feel like their pho actually came with too MUCH meat, clocking in at almost half a pound of sliced beef: so much that, for the first time ever, I actually ran out of noodles before I did meat! Did I just complain about too much meat, you ask? Yes I did. But it's not really a terrible problem to have, at all.

The spring rolls and imperial rolls we got as appetizers from them were also pretty solid, but, definitely come here for the pho.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - A decently sized venue with a good amount of accessible seating. If I recall correctly though, table arrangements are such that, when the place is packed, maneuvering through the restaurant does require a little more work.

Bathroom - Didn't check them out, so no comment.
author: Johnny W.

description:
I eat here all the time. This food is so good. The Service is great and friendly. If you want pho this is place to go the other food is great also. This has been my favorite place to eat for the last year. 
Support local business.
author: Terry L.

description:
Solid bowl of pho. A little greasy as other people have mentioned but overall hit the spot when you are craving a bowl. 

As most people should know...the area is very very sketchy so tourists beware! Walk quickly, keep your head down and you'll be fine :)

Cash only
author: Cathy F.

description:
Phos were huge and had lots of meat! Soup was flavorful but the noodles were overdone which resulted in a mushy mess. Spring rolls were crispy and tasty. Summer rolls were also very good.

Located on a quiet block with quite a few homeless people.
author: Elizabeth N.

description: They did it again. Fantastic beef Pho kho (dry Pho). Seasoned Pho noodles accompanied w/ a tangy sauce. Lots of herbs and meat fixings (flank, ribeye, tripe) and fragrant broth. Always worth the visit. So much fun to eat. Note: CASH ONLY. To go orders ready within minutes.
author: Carina L.

description:
Ordered the "dry pho" here. It is served with broth and fish sauce on the side. I didn't use any of the broth, because it tasted great without it. The bowl that housed my dry pho was fairly large. It came savory, large pieces of fatty meat. The noodles had an oily texture to it and tasted great.

I barely finished my order, even though I enjoyed it very much. After admiring the empty bowl, I felt extremely satisfied, but began to wonder wtf I just ate. The dry pho definitely wasn't made for anyone counting calories, but it'll take the hangry out of you each and every time. 

The owner is quite a character. He speaks really fast and will answer his own questions -  before you can answer them. My friend tried to order a thai iced tea here and the owner's reaction was hilarious. "You want pad thai with that too? I know a good place for that, but this is viet restaurant."

Its kind of obvious, but parking really sucks around here.
author: David Z.

description:
Quick service and tasty, authentic pho with generous portions- I usually have trouble finishing a "small" bowl, let alone the large which is bigger than my head.

The only downside is it's cash only, but that's pretty usual for the Tenderloin and the food is worth a trip to my bank ATM beforehand.

$15 including tip is enough to fill me up for the evening- lot of bang for the buck!
author: Priscilla M.

description:
Excellent service. 
I am an idiot and can't read basic words or understand pictures, and accidentally ordered noodles without soup, but when I asked about the soup they immediately explained the dish I ordered to me, brought me a bowl of delicious broth, and kept offering to give me a different dish even though it was 110% my fault. Anyways, I declined, since the vermicelli noodles came with the perfect amount of vegetable seasoning and meat and with the broth were perfect. Egg rolls were good as well. 

Cash only, most dishes less than $10
author: Sharon H.

description:
it took me a while to warm up to the idea of pho. i used to not like the broth at allll. but now? pho is the ultimate hangover food. perfect cure to that throbbing headache in the morning.

came here on sunday after a holiday party - they open early, which is so nice! that neighborhood is fullll of cheap good eats (chutnney, kare ken, etc.) and pho tan hoa fits the bill.  we walk in and the restaurant is about half full.  its a seat yourself kinda situation, and we're brought waters immediately.  perhaps they could tell that i needed hydration..? teehee.

i decide pretty quickly that i want the spring rolls (with large thing of peanut sauce), a large bowl of beef pho, and beef stew with rice. everything comes out in less than 10 minutes. we immediately KILL the rolls, so delicious.. and we made the peanut sauce spicy. nomsies. we split the pho, and had a few bites of the beef stew. pho is 5 stars, beef stew is 3, and the rolls 4, soooo average rating 4! anyhoooo! it was good, really cheap, and cured my headache. wooo!

service is friendly. the owner is funny. and the restaurant is clean. mmm!
author: Christina L.

description: Stopped here for a quick lunch and ordered the Seafood Chow Fun. Solid, no nonsense service, tea provided with a nice glass of water. The dish was hot and flavorful. Nice mix of seafood and the noodles were well prepared and seasoned. Add some chili oil for a little kick. If in the neighborhood, it's worth a try. Most others were having pho and it looked solid.
author: Dimitri S.

description:
Pho here is delicious and my favorite in SF.    I'm a NYer and compare my Pho to Vietnamese Mecca (SoCal:  Pho Kimmy).   This place is not close to being equivalent to Mecca but it sure beats any place in NYC so I always eat here when I'm in town.  

Their Goi Cuon (summer roll with shrimp, pork, herbs and rice noodles) were terrific and highly recommended.   Crack heads still there - right outside.   They are hard to predict as they stumble in your way as you try to enter this restaurant.   Likely explains why they close at sundown and put the gates up so don't make the mistake and go their for dinner if the sun is down!!!     

Recommended:

Pho 
Bun Bo Hue (for those in the know- rookies need not order)
Goi Cuon (summer rolls)
author: Loc V.

description:
If I went by service this would be a three star.   I went by appearance this would be a two star.  If I went by neighborhood this would be a one star.  But, if I go by food quality and experience alone, this is a five!  
I never heard of Dry Pho.  Ain't got that back in Baltimore, hon.  Its amazing.  The summer rolls, broth, bun, tea, and sauces were sublime.  
When we walked in, we were the only Occidentals for a while.  The boss/waiter could care less. I said I loved the meal.  He said, "OK, cash only".
author: Mel S.

description:
I'm a big fan of this place. I live right across the street. I'll begin by getting my less favorable bits out of the way.

The place closes early. It's really a breakfast/brunch place...as it is in Vietnamese culture. I would LOVE it if this place was open past 3pm.

Its a bit pricey. While I definitely think its worth it, a plate of shrimp fresh rolls are $9. Granted, there's 4 of them. But all i really want is 2 and it would be great if that was an option.

The noodle bowls are great...get the pork and spring roll one. The pho is amazing. Sure, I've read the reviews that say the broth is too dark. It's not clear, and that's because its made with all the deliciousness of beef (marrow?). I think the broth is great and I swear it will cure any ailment. The best part is the rare beef. The beef is good quality and the servings are large. The medium bowl is hard to finish.
author: Sarah S.

description:
AWESOME!

I am vegetarian and was taken here by colleagues.  I was bit nervous at first because all of the pho broths were non-vegetarian and was unsure if I could get something to eat.  That is their specially - Pho.

The waiter was gentle and helpful as he suggested chow mein or chow fun with fresh veggies.  Great, I thought, something to eat.

When the plate arrived it was a large and beautiful display of locally made, fresh egg noodles topped with wonderfully cooked fresh vegetables.  The noodles were the flat kind, like an Asian linguini and they were a delicious bed supporting the vegetables and then all of it topped with fresh cilantro.

The taste was as exceptional as the appearance.  The portion was as pleasing as the price.

This has truly gone down as the best plate of chow mein I have ever had.
author: A. D.

description: They have really good chicken Pho. Big portions, so a small bowl would be good even for guys. The owner is friendly although it's kind of hard to understand him with his strong accent.
author: Sunny C.

description: What a hidden gem! This place is about as legit as you can get. It was filled with Vietnamese people, and the server was tough to understand, so we knew we chose the right place. Ordered a medium bowl with rare steak. The medium was monstrous. I can't imagine how anyone can finish a large! Everything came out quick, and was absolutely delicious. The neighborhood is a bit rough - junkies on every corner, but it was worth the walk
author: Diana E.

description:
Flew cross country. Hangray. Wanted some phõ. Yelp helped! 
Place has great pho. Got the rare beef and shrimp. Delicious. 
Cash only. Lots of homeless. Worth it.
author: MJ A.

description: Coming from Vietnam, I have to say this a a decent pho with a lot of meat. The soup tastes just nice. The noodle (banh pho) isn't authentic though. It is normally flat type of rice noodle. My friend got his grilled pork an fried spring roll. The spring roll is really good.
author: Vy T.

description:
Pho Tan Hoa exemplifies everything I hate about San Francisco. 

Fucking Tenderloin... As I'm walk through the piss smelling, shit smeared streets that are the Tenderloin and getting close to my destination (Pho Tan Hoa) I see a homely [homeless] women screaming obscenities at 2 arresting police officers.  They are standing in front of a restaurant.  Turns out that it's my destination.  I step up, right outside the restaurant and say "Hi guys... I'm trying to get lunch in the place that you're blocking.  Please let me through" - All 3 of them look at me, stupified before simultaneously taking a step to my left and allowing me in for some noodles.

While I ordered, waited, and consumed my brothy noodley goodness, the charade kept going, with said homely women screaming at the the offices, and the officers getting defensive, putting the women on the ground, cuffing and reading her, her rights.  Everyone in the restaurant stared. Staff, patrons, everyone.

That said, the pho was great... broth was fantastic, noodles were perfection, meats were delicious.  Service was rude-ish, but I sort of anticipated it.  Atmosphere was shit, but again, it was what was expected.  Their noodles made up for all of these follies, hence the 4 star rating (no really... the pho was absolutely amazing... It gives me wet dreams...)

Pho and a show.  Fucking Tenderloin.
author: Josh D.

description:
No frills Vietnamese restaurant. I went in for lunch and ordered the small rare beef and brisket pho. 
This big bowl of goodness came to my table in less than 5 minutes.  Broth is very tasty and low in fat. Served with lots of beef and noodles, fresh basil, lemon, chili and bean sprouts. Service was very friendly.
author: Cristina H.

description: Pho Tan Hoa is the best Vietnamese place in San Francisco. I visited Vietnam last April and this place rivals some of the best we had over there. It is always busy but there is never a wait. The service is efficient and friendly and makes sure we are always taken care of. Some must tries are the raw beef salad, egg noodle pho, and pork vermicelli salad. If you are looking for a great Vietnamese spot in the city, don't go anywhere else and go here!
author: Steph G.

description: My belly is so happy right now.  This was really great hangover food.  My buddy and I are considering taking a beer bong and pouring our Pho in it next time.
author: Ross Z.

description: Terrible service. The main guy put me in the back when there were tables in the front. When another customer sat next to my table, he moved the napkins and the sauces over to him. The food came and it was the saltiest pho I've had in my life. I couldn't even finish it. I didn't complain but I did raise my hand. The guy saw me raise my hand, made eye contact with me and left. I waited 5 minutes and he didn't come back. I went up to pay and tipped 10 cents. My mouth is still parched.
author: Jimmy C.

description: Cheap and portion-wise large. A little bit too sweet for my taste, but within reasonable range.
author: Yi D.

description:
The pho ga at Pho Tan Hoa is a MUST.

The day after a long night of drinking and clubbing, my friend and I came to Pho Tan Hoa. I ordered the pho ga while he ordered the dry pho (which he recommended).

The pho ga had huge flavor and had a lot of garnish compared to other pho gas where its just noodle and chicken. The bowl was quite large so I didn't get a chance to finish it so I took it home instead. I pulled out the container of pho ga and microwaved it for a bit and it still tasted amazing. It was actually really impressive.

Will definitely be back here when I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Mabel Y.

description:
With a bunch of New Yorkers who really wanted to try Vietnamese food from San Fran since ppl say it's better than NY. The spring rolls and summer rolls are definitely   better. But it is also a lot more $$. The soup base tastes more home made and less msg. There were a lot more meat like all other reviewer stated but I didn't like the noodle. It has a rubbery/elastic texture that's kinda weird. 

I dunno about other Viet restaurants but this one seems to be located in the Ghetto. There was a male cross dresser who approached and pushed up against our rear car window after we parked. Weird!
author: Xiao S.

description:
Little hole in the wall that is AMAZING. 

I came here while on keto (high fat no carb diet) and was drooling over the grilled pork vermicelli bowl and ordered it with no noodles. They generously filled up the order with veggies. So yum. 

We also got the pho too and the broth was SO good. 

Would definitely eat here again. Too yummy.
author: Austin L.

description: Good food - love dried pho here. So tasty and clean inside.... Finally definitely come back
author: Jessica M.

description:
It was a 0.8 (10 minute walk) from FiDi and downtown, but well worth it for my team's weekly #PhoMondays meal. The quality beats anything downtown, especially for the various beef pho bowls.

The place is clean, spacious, and food comes fast. The owner/head guy who took our order is a master of upselling Vietnamese drip coffee, quail eggs, and upsizes with his tantalizing slash hypnotic auctioneer voice.

The beef special bowl (small $8.50) is really really big. Forget the medium/large, a small is most place's large. The bowl is perfect, tons of meat on stacks of meats that you'll need to pull apart.

4.5 i'll be back. The chicken bowl I was told is meh, skip it. Beef bowl all the way!
author: Chuck N.

description:
Wow, by far the best pho in San Fran. After two days of adventuring for all the local pho spots while on a work trip, I was left feeling very disappointed. Most shops offer small portions, bad noodles, and worst of all, bad broth, many times oily. Not here!

I rarely meet a bowl of pho that I cannot finish, and if it wasn't so delicious, I would've gave up. But it was so good, I had to finish every bite. The tendon pieces were massive, the brisket melts in your mouth, the beef balls were chewy, and the rare beef was tender. Man their ingredients are top notch. And oh, the noodles were bouncy and perfectly cooked. 


I highly recommend this place for your pho fix. Next time I'm in SF in December I will be coming here.
author: Christina And Terence T.

description: The times when cravings hit you so hard because it hadn't been satisfied the first time. Bigger bowl with a deeply rich broth and loaded with Tendon and Tripe certainly helps. Makes my hand look small. I could have face planted in the soup but I drank almost all of it. That's how good it was
author: Dawen H.

description:
Ordered the chicken pho with young eggs. It was my first time having young eggs and it is just like a firmer, smaller egg yolk. At first, I was disappointed. Where's my chicken, I thought. But as I started eating the pho, I noticed more pieces of meat popping up to the top of my bowl and the noodles disappearing. Holy moly the meat to noodle ratio was awesome! 

Broth: 
The soup was flavorful and HOT. Like I couldn't see out of my glasses after the second slurp because the broth was so steamy. YES! Just how it's supposed to be. 

Chicken:
So tender and flavorful! Slices of dark and white meat are scattered around the bowl. 

Noodles:
Not clumpy, soggy or gritty. 

Service:
The moment we walked in we were seated. In less than 10 minutes we were slurping our noodles. No, the waiters don't have the most patience but that's expected. 

Cash Only. 

Will be back to try other menu items!
author: Michelle C.

description:
This place was #2 on our weekly Pho-venture and wasn't sure what to expect. The restaurant wasn't in the nicest of SF areas but I can't judge a place by it's location, really. I ordered a small beef pho noodle bowl with rare steak & tendon. The owner who took our order was super super nice and kept us entertained while we ordered and the wait wasn't too long. Our food came and the first thing I noticed was the high quality meat that was piled on high! Beautiful succulent beef! The broth was flavorful (better than a lot of places I've been to so far) and the small was more like a med/ large. Portions were huge! Everything was so delicious. 

I rate this place a 4.5 - only docked half a star due to the ratio of noodles vs meats. I felt like there were more meats than the noodles could accomodate lol. But hey it could be a good thing for some people. This place is flavor-town and I'd gladly walk 0.8 miles to come here again!
author: Rehana K.

description: Quick service. Severely overpriced for a place that is cash only. It should be $2 cheaper. Ambiance is a bit homely in an unsafe neighborhood. And did i mention, just avg pho? Skip if you arent dying of hunger
author: Jeffrey W.

description: Really solid delicious "hole in the wall" pho. My buddy Ben took me. My #24 no noodles hit the spot. Will return!
author: Andrew K.

description:
- Spacious environment.
- Friendly service, helpful staff and delivers well on condiment portions. (I asked for more white raw onion and got a ton).
- They ask you if you want your rare steak on the side
- Large size #7 is for 2 stomachs, $10.50 for all the beef parts they offer in the biggest bowl you've probably ever had
- Amount of meat is on the lower side, taste is OK
- Pretty tasty broth
- Noodles are OK
- Cash only, pay at counter
- Food comes out fast
author: Gabe L.

description:
We finally went in and tried this place. It's on our street in the lovely Tenderloin so we pass by it all the time. 

For appetizer we had the fried rolls.. I would skip those. $9 for small rolls and they are not Vietnamese rolls in my opinion. 

For main I had medium bowl of the beef pho with beef ball and beef slices. The broth was probably one of the best I've had. So flavorful. The hubs had the seafood pho which had a different lighter broth that was also very good. Both came with rice noodles. I saw a large bowl of pho and I'd say that's too big but if you're hungry why not. 

As mentioned by others, cash only. Service was good and efficient. There are many more items on their menu that we'd like to try so we'll def be back.
author: Vol T.

description: This place is nice and big, cash only, and located in a pretty central area. The pho was delicious but different from the normal kind of pho that I'm more accustomed to. The broth is dark and non translucent and did not have as much star of anise or spice flavor. However portions are great with lots of noodle and lots of high quality beef. Overall I'd recommend it!
author: Joanne K.

description:
CASH ONLY!! Nothing too special about their pho. Had their Pho Ga and it came with a decent amount of chicken, cilantro, and noodles. Their small is HUGE--more like a medium--but they do charge $8.85/bowl to compensate for their bigger portions.

My friend ordered a medium ($9.30) Pho Dac Biet and, instead of being given extra meat, noodles, tendon, etc., they were handed an extra bowl of broth. (Their pho was served in a small bowl) I've never seen that happen before... 

Aside from pho they also offer a wide variety of rice/dry noodle (vermicelli) plates, chow fun, chow mien, egg rolls, spring rolls, and many drink options.

Service was decent and food came out lightening fast! We did, however, have to wave down our waitress a few times for water refills but other than that she was very nice. For overall cleanliness I'd give this place a 2/5. Probably wouldn't go out of my way to come here again as it is in a bad part of town and there are better Vietnamese restaurants towards Chinatown/Japantown.
author: Steph M.

description:
Amazing place!

This is probably the best Vietnamese restaurant in downtown, love their lemon raw beef and short rib over rice. The owner is super nice, there was one time my friend didn't realize left his bag in the restaurant and the owner ran out with the bag and catch us (we were almost two blocks away).
author: Davis L.

description:
Great recovery food after a hazzy night out. Found this gem after the first 2 places were closed :( 

We were little turned away with it being CASH only, but were informed that there was an atm inside. Not sure the fee as I actually had cash on me. We got a table immediately as we walked in, it was around maybe 11ish. Good customer service. And the food was great. A buddy of mine got an XL and said there was plenty of meat; usually they just add more noodles but in this case they really took care of us. Also very fair pricing.

It does get busy; the turnaround on tables is quick but the walk in traffic picks up throughout the day.
author: Brian S.

description: I come here just for the seafood dry pho.  It is sooo good!  their beef pho is good as well.
author: Love L.

description:
this is one of my favorite Vietnamese restaurants in the city. I go here once a while I crave viet food. 

service is wonderful: u get seated fast and ur food is served instantly. 

food here is also very good, and the quantity is amazing. 

dry pho noodle is one of my favorites here.. 

their noodle bun salads are also good, and so are their rice plates. 

I haven't had any bad experience here either with the food or service. highly recommend
author: Steve S.

description:
The background: Vietnamese Pho Restaurant with a lot of other vietnamese dishes like rice, vermicelli (bun), egg noodles and various appetizers and desserts. Pretty comprehensive, but their speciality lies in the pho. 

The details: I got the special beef pho, the one that ONLY comes in jumbo size, which is probably more than enough for 2 people. It was about $9, and contains everything: from tripe to beef balls. If you're new to pho, just get this, it'll have everything for you to try. I loved the quantity of this and the broth was delicious -- I didn't feel the MSG hangover later (the extreme thirst and icky feeling post heavy MSG meals). I often judge a vietnamese restaurant by how clean their bean sprouts are and these were perfect, white fresh and the ends had been plucked off! A+. Service was ok - very cut and dry: order, food appears fast, no small talk in between. When you pay, the check doesn't come to you, you just go up. Cash only!

The verdict: I liked this place a lot, but the fact that I can realistically never feel safe eating dinner here (or after dark) is a big bummer. The neighborhood is a bit on the rough side, but manageable in the sun with a group of friends.
author: Christine B.

description:
This place is on point!!! Morning Pho MMM now that's what I call breakfast.

The food was fresh the veggies were crisp and vibrant (no wilted basil). The food was enough to satisfy my cravings for the day.  Soup is flavorful, but typical for a pho place. 

If you're at a hotel and want some pho before you check out then drop by here to get your fix.

Note the place was packed on a Sunday morning at 9-10ish
author: Derick F.

description: Friendly and prompt service. Affordable and generous portions. I ordered #7 and it is more than enough for one person. Soup was well-flavored and not greasy. Meat-soup-noodle ratio was good. I only ordered for take-away but the place looked tidy and clean when I walked in. Cash only.
author: HM N.

description:
I liked this place. 
Decent pho.
Five spice chicken was a bit dry but flavorful.
The help didn't seem to speak much english but was enough to get by.
Not big on ambiance but almost no pho place is. It's clean though. 
All in all, pretty good for your viet fix. However, Golden Star is a bit better to me. Check out my review on that.
author: Ming C.

description:
This is a strait pho treat.  Noodles were great, meat was plentiful (beef). Servers were very nice, though they were not English speakers; but what do you really need words for?  Just point at a picture, and they bring you that dish.  I know a lot of people bitch about the price, but medium beef combo was $10.85 out the door.  These brothers need to make a buck too, so it seemed reasonable enough to me.  

Medium was perfect for a breakfast/lunch portion for an average to big appetite.
author: Steve M.

description: The pho here is pretty good, lots of noodles and beef. I would say this place is better than Kevin's noodle house
author: anthony j.

description:
cash only!!!! but.. they have an ATM in the back.

best pho in the city!  the price tag is a bit hefty with ~$10 for a medium, but the dishes are authentic, nicely portioned and i love the pho here with beef on the side.  my dad used to take me here as a kid and i would always enjoy every moment of it.  

pho combo w/ beef on the side - they give a lot of noodles for the medium and for the large, it's HUGE!!!!  i enjoyed the broth as it came out piping hot and they don't skimp on noodles and the meat.  btw beef on the side (.75) and they bring you a separate bowl of soup to dip the meat in.  make sure to dip it when it's hot, so it cooks, but i love to self-marinade the meat in some lemon juice and pepper before in dip it in the broth.

vermicelli w/ bbq pork and imperial rolls - huge portion, but i found the pork to be a bit too salty.  it went well with all the noodles, veggies, fish sauce and imperial rolls.  i wouldn't recommend just eating the bbq pork by itself.  

overall - would come here if i am in the tenderloin, but a bit out of my way and not the best place to roam in SF.  beware of where you park and also the neighborhood!  the service wasn't bad, but the owner knows my dad as an usual, so maybe that made a diff.  i like this place and i look forward to come here every time on a family day. =)
author: Josie L.

description: I don't think this PHO worth 4 stars in yelp. My main concern is there beef and rice noodles. The rare beef was not fresh. I can see ice in it. And the rice noodles stick together and hard to split.
author: Irene Y.

description: Yummy! Large portions and a good staff. We didn't have to wait long. Their pho is legit.
author: Linh L.

description:
If you are not some pho stickler and just want some good ol' pho, you really cant go wrong with this place. 

First of all, the location is fantastic. A couple blocks towards the tenderloin from union square; maybe took us about 5-10 minutes getting there. It is a good sized restaurant for a city.

Second, the service wasn't too bad. The waiter spoke really broken English and it was sometimes difficult to understand him. But he and the rest of the staff were nice (at least the nicest I've ever encountered in a pho restaurant)

Third, and probably most importantly, the food and portions were fantastic. I don't remember what number it was, but I had the large combination pho. They had STACKS of brisket in that pho when it came out. It was a pho for big boys...and I felt like a big boy after finishing it. It tasted really good.

So why not 5 stars, or even 4? The bean sprouts looked like they were left behind in the 70's. They are cash only, the spring rolls were a little to obviously old, and they use A LOT of MSG. Sure, maybe its because I ordered a large pho. But I always order larges, and my throat was never quite on fire like it was after I went here...

Still, would I come back? Hell yeah...
author: Justin L.

description:
I had high hopes for this place as it had so many good reviews. 
some ppl even claimed this place to be the best pho place in SF. 
I have my favorite pho place around the same area but I thought I'd try a few other pho places to see if I can find better pho. 
but as soon as I tried the broth I was disappointed. the broth is not clear and deep. it wasn't flavorful for me. plus it is pricy for a vet restaurant in TL. you can usually get a large bowl for 8 in TL but it was over 10$. 
I'm gonna stick with pho2000.
author: Carli C.

description: As other reviews have commented, it is cash only, and it is pretty busy.  So we stood in line for a table.  The turnover is pretty good though, so we waited about 5-10 mins. for a party of 5.  Many more tables for 2 opened up before ours.  It reminds me of Chinatown, since the tables are basic and some are butted up again each other, so you may be dining right next to other diners.  They do a good job of bussing and cleaning the tables, however, and service is very fast.  I think the owner took our order.  He's very matter-of-fact, so don't expect a friendly, personable waiter.  The pho, however, was very good.  On the menu, it shows three sizes of the house special pho.  Below this are listed many other varieties, all in the small size.  All the varieties are available in three sizes, however- small, medium, and large.  We all ordered the medium size and it was just right.  The broth was wonderful!  We also ordered the shrimp salad rolls, which were fresh and delish!  If you are squeamish and a clean-freak, this might not be the place for you.  We loved it though.  We would definitely go back!
author: Dale H.

description: Pho sure the number one pho joint in the Tenderloin. Phonomenal.
author: Alexander T.

description: Love this place and the staff! My non Asian colleague commented that it was the best meal for the entire business trip. We did eat at some nice high end places, but nothing beats a good bowl of pho, bun and Vietnamese ice coffee. Ed this place.
author: Soo B.

description: I came here on a Saturday afternoon an hour before closing (the close at 4pm). I grew up coming here for their beef stew and bread. Surprisingly, it was just as good as I remember although the meat was a bit tougher than usual.. It was a combination of beef and tendons. The sauce was delicious, but would be better if it was less oily. We ordered a bun bo hue (spicy beef noodle soup), a number 7 large beef noodle soup, beef stew and bread, and a lemon soda. The bill came out around $36 which was expected. The beef noodle soup was okay.. It wasn't concentrated enough with flavor and I've definitely has better at other locations. But, the portion was pretty good for a large. The bun bo hue was pretty good, but again I've had better.  It wasn't beefy enough but had a good spicy kick to it. There was a pretty strong shrimp taste to it, which I think others would mind. One thing I did like about the bun bo hue is that it came with a bit of lemon grass, onions and cilantro for extra flavor. Overall, the food came out extremely fast!Restaurant is CASH ONLY, so make sure to visit a bank before hand.
author: Kimberly H.

description: We don't know what happened in the 2+ years since we were here last but this place definitely has gone downhill. The pho was far from great and we were quite disappointed. We had hoped to have the great broth that we had before, as my husband used to be a regular here when he lived down in the area, but he even says that it is not the same.. Sad. At least the prices are still reasonable.
author: Rachel O.

description: Authentic Vietnamese food. Good value, fast service.  The pho here is my favorite. It costs a little more than other places, but it's worth it.
author: Lee P.

description:
My Favorite Place to Pho!

Granted, I don't venture outside of the Tenderloin enough for my Asian food, but I know there's good reason to. There are so many amazing options here, it's hard to leave! Until I explore the Sunset and Richmond districts more, I can't call this place the "best" for Pho, but I can still call it "My Favorite Place to Pho!" I've had many dishes here, but my staple is (sounds like) "nambah sic-deen, wey-ah beep an ten-dan"...that would be "number sixteen, rare beef and tendon." The "house special" combo pho is bomb! I can't always finish it all, but you will see me try! The brisket is tender, the rare beef slices are fresh, the tendon is thick, yet softened to perfection, and the broth is opaque. The way good Pho should be! The other dishes are good, but not great. My stars are for the Pho.
author: Helen L.

description:
Hung over in the city. 

Where to get decent Pho? In San Jose, not SF, and we were right. This pho wasn't good! It was sure busy and the tables weren't clean for us to sit, the guy was so rude...We just sat down and then the head guy started directing his men to clean. We know how Vietnamese people work (cause we're Viet) so we spoke Viet and then that's when he got nicer to us and provided slightly better service. Yes, using our cute little Vietnamese charm. But seriously $10 for a bowl of pho!? And the pho wasn't even good! It was just like drinking oil broth. It lacked so much flavor, thank god for siracha! But they sure give you hella meat & noodles! We had like a stack of beef left in our bowls, it was waaaay to excessive. (Even for me!) Even though this pho sucks, People probably think it's the only "good pho" in SF for the area. Our friend lives in SF and we had to settle...next time we'll be hitting our hometown for some good ole Pho... SJ. lol
author: Lisa W.

description: $9.75 for a bowl of pho? I think not! The service here needs work as well. You guys should be grateful we were that hung over & needed something soupy. 1/5 Stars!
author: Jason F.

description:
SF Ghetto. This is where you will find one of the best place for Pho. Excellent.

[Full disclosure: I have not received any compensation for writing this review. I have no material connection to the businesses, brands, products, or services that I have reviewed. I have the right to update any review in the future.]
author: James W.

description:
I might have been cussed at, or I might have been complimented by my server/guy who I believe was just yelling random numbers at me. Nevertheless, this place is authentic and a great place to have a wide variety of delicious Pho. I defaulted to my rubbery goodness that is beef balls in broth--no, not the Rocky Mountain Oyster type, but a mystery meat that is chewy and delicious. I also tried some of the raw beef and tendons Pho, which was also quite delicious. 

The neighborhood has a large homeless population surrounding it, which I'm used to, but I could see some being wary of walking there. That being said, I had zero issues.
author: Mark S.

description:
Great family-run business in the loin, but don't fret if you don't speak Vietnamese. They speak English pretty well, there are pictures and the owner is super friendly and greets all of his customers with a smile. 

The portions are a bit pricer, but they are large! Ingredients are fresh, but the pho broth was a bit sweet for me. Also, the egg rolls were mostly vegetable and wrapping. There was very little pork in the filling and the filing was a tad too sweet also. My favorite dish of theirs is the bun Bo Hue. It's very favourful and comes with all the neccessary ingredients such as pork blood, pigs feet, etc. 

Three stars for the food and one star for the friendly experience.  If you're craving Vietnamese food and don't want to venture too far away from Union Square, then I recommend you give this place a try. The walk is a bit scary---two blocks through the Tenderloin district where you'll smell lots of pee and see lots of homeless people, but don't fear, SF is very safe.
author: alicia k.

description:
Soup and shenanigans in the Tenderloin. The guy that runs the place is hilarious; welcoming you with his mumbling orders of where to sit. 

The staff if friendly, the service is fast, and the phô is good. Through the window in the heart of the Tenderloin, there is life. Some up to no good and some up to all good. It's active and entertaining and what I love about this city.  

This place is always full at lunchtime, but if you're looking for dinner, you will need to come early because they close at 5:30p.
author: Marsizzle M.

description:
One of the best bowls of pho and bun (bbq pork) I've had in SF. 
Great portion sizes, reasonable prices, tasty and fresh food, good service (once you get it). They close early, so try to visit during a weekend lunch if you don't work nearby.
author: Cindy Y.

description:
Was staying at the Hilton next door for our work kick off, just couldn't face eating the standard buffet on our lunch break. 

Yelp is my friend! 1 block & 2min walk into the 'loin is where I will satisfy my Bun Bo Hue craving. Massive portion! I actually couldn't finish it, well I did order a large at $9, eyes bigger than ma belly & all that. 

Not the most flavourful, but satisfied my needs & I enjoyed every mouthful.

Ps beware of the crackheads! You just don't get this in the UK & I've been brought up around S.London! Why is SF so tolerable to these bums is beyond me!
author: Gar Wing L.

description:
YOU "WAHH SCARY NEIGHBORHOOD" WHINERS! GET THE HELL OUTTA HERE, PUSS.

This place have damn good pho, reasonable prices, and an owner says "HI- HI- HELLO- HI" when you step in. He's hard to talk to but gets your orders just right. Good 'nough for me. Oh, also he remembers returning customers, which is really good.

Their classic pho is best in town. I've been to Washington, Oregon, and LA but this place was the best for me - but that's personal. 

Also they have this "Dry pho" - which is their signature dish. It's like a pho separated with soup. IT IS DAMN GOOD. TRY IT.

If you like pho, go to this place, get a bowl you like and leave 12 bucks on table and get out. You'll leave satisfied.
author: Brandon K.

description: This place was really good! I got the seafood pho soup with seafood. Very busy too, so you know the food is fresh. Would definitely come back again.
author: Amirah Q.

description:
HUGE bowls.. in fact out of the 8 people, none of us finished our food. The mediums look the same as smalls, though maybe with more noodles? SO MUCH MEAT and you never say that about pho.
Plenty of room for big groups, especially a big hungover group needing pho in their stomachs STAT.
Service was spotty.. though the water was refilled quickly, I could only understand half of what they were saying/asking and they did deliver some wrong stuff.
Oh and there was food on our "clean" chopsticks, yeah gross.
You do need to walk through some of the sketchier blocks of the city to get your pho too.
author: Vivian H.

description:
I got a #23, which is is the Beef Pho with well done brisket, and a condensed milk coffee. 

First, a prologue. I spent the last two summers in Seattle, which I consider the Pho capital of the West Coast. I went to pronouncing Pho "Foe" to speaking fluent Vietnamese solely via osmosis after spending hours and hours in Pho joints. The Pho was cheap, delicious, and consistent. This is a Pho/Chinese restaurant, which seems weird to me. A similar comparison would be having a joint German/Italian restaurant. I get they are on the same continent but... why? 

At Pho Tan Hoa, I'd put the Pho in the so-so range. The noodles and broth were quite good. They had the salt/fat ratio down perfectly, and the broth had some time to soak into the noodles giving them some of the flavor. I was surprised they didn't have an extra noodle option on the menu, it's worth asking for them as they are the best part of the Pho. 

My main beef was with the brisket. Frankly, they used a really poor cut that had a lot of connective tissue and not nearly as much meat as I'd expect. I'm totally good with two solid slices of brisket, but I'm not going to get excited for 5 pieces of overcooked brisket that is more collagen than protein. 

I'm still looking for my cheap Pho option in the bay. I need my fix, and this ain't it.
author: Jake B.

description: This was my first time trying this place and it definitely won't be my last. I ordered the Pho Kho (dry noodle) and it was superb.
author: Mark C.

description: Excellent and authentic. Waiters are super friendly and food was great. We loved every dish.
author: F V.

description: This place is in the middle of the TL, parking was tough to find. The restaurant has plenty of seating! I ordered the pho tai! Nice great flavored beef broth! There was SO much beef I was almost full just eating the beef! I usually like lime with my pho but they gave lemon wedges. It's overall a great bowl of pho and will be coming back!
author: Amber J.

description:
I have no clue what the owner is saying when he talks to me but the food is damn good. I usually get the rare steak and brisket, both cuts of meat are very tender and of high quality, the broth is light and refreshing. The prices here are a bit higher than most pho restaurants but it's not unreasonable. 

Not the best neighborhood, so get in and get out before you get shanked. Cash only.
author: Jake B.

description:
My sister and I stumbled across this restaurant while heading unknowingly through the Tenderlion district. We were starving, craving something Asian and affordable, and in my sister's words, "dodged some bums" to get here for some good food. 

Fortunately it was still open around 3PM on a Saturday afternoon even though there was nobody else there. I ordered my default Tai Sach (rare beef pho), and my sister ordered the vermicelli with charbroiled shrimp/pork. The portions were actually perfect for me because I was able to finish my food (normally pho comes with so much meat), but the bowl is not as big as the ones you'd get in LA. The most memorable part of the meal was probably the charbroiled pork in the vermicelli. Sweet and savory, and oh so tender. It wasn't dry and tasted almost like chicken. 

Cash only, so make sure you bring the dollah bills, or else you'll have to use the ATM machine outside the restaurant to get some. Price was a little steeper than what I'm used to ($18 bill total when it would be $13 in LA), but ah well, it's SF. Ce'st la vie!
author: Dorothy X.

description: I probably did two things wrong. First I ordered the pho chicken which wasn't adventurous and therefore not special. Good but not special. Then I ordered it as take out. Assembling it and eating from a tall plastic container was not ideal.
author: A M.

description:
Came here after a night of going out, luckily for me it is only 4 blocks away! We arrived at 11.30am and we were able to sit down right away. 

We ordered: BBQ Pork Vermicelli bowl, Vietnamese coffee, Chicken egg noodle bowl, beef pho. I loved the BBQ Pork, it was cooked to perfection, I would order that by itself. The coffee was extremely strong, but tasty - I only drank a quarter of the cup. 

A little pricey, but I am comparing it to the sunset.
author: Natasha S.

description:
Gotta lower this down to 4 stars because I tried the Beef Pho (Large with everything in it), and man do they skimp on meat. I paid $10 for a huge bowl hoping for a ton of meat, but it turned out to be mostly broth and noodles. It is not bad, but I think I'll stick with pho ga from now on, and the small size is plenty big.

The bun was good, but also very skimpy on the toppings.
author: Jess C.

description: All I got to say is dhiarea.  This was the only thing I ate all day the beef and beef ball pho and eggrolls. The beef soup and beef had that weird old meat iron taste. I said to my friend this taste funky and I joked lets see what happens in a few hours. Dhiarea happened.
author: Karen T.

description:
Good pho and no fuss. Yes there are crack heads around but who cares, its good food. 

Although I did go today, Thursday and it was closed. I was utterly disappointed and thats putting it mildly. Anyone know if this placed closed officially or was it a freak moment? I have been told by my coworker who has been going here for like 10 years that they close on Tuesdays not Thursdays...
author: Kristan B.

description: Fast service. A little pricey. Cash only which sucks. Pho wasn't that great. The owner was hard to understand. We called to see if they were busy but they just hung up. I would try a different pho place next time in SF.
author: Sonny X.

description:
You can order a Small, Medium, or Large size soup. The broth is delicious. They throw a lot of onions and cilantro in. All of the ingredients were extremely fresh. 

The service was fast and friendly, and the food is very inexpensive. 

I wish they made Vietnamese sandwiches, but that's okay. They do serve Chinese food. 

The restaurant is really clean, besides the mop bucket and trash cans in the bathroom. 

They have delicious hot tea. 

I love this place!
author: Michelle W.

description:
Probably the most expensive Vietnamese hole-in-the-wall I've been to (even a small bowl of pho will run you $9 before tax), and it's a hidden gem in the way that someone might think to cache a gem behind a gauntlet of crackheads and pooppigeons. 

You do get a ton of meat in your bowl, but somehow that's not a plus here. The meat/tendon is all so thick that at some point, you're just dying for noodles or simply for someone to take back the supersizing in the kitchen. The broth also is nothing to call home about since it's a one-note blast of Meat Meat Meat. Maybe save this place for emerging from the wilderness sometime down the line.
author: Kevin L.

description:
I ordered the medium pho (#8 on the menu) which came with your usual assortment of beef, tripe, and everything yummy. The medium size was more than enough to satisfy my pho craving and I noticed the soup had a distinct sweetness to it. I was even beginning to think maybe they didn't put MSG in the broth.

NOPE. After I left and ventured to Union Square, I found myself extremely thirsty and disappointed. I'm sure there are better places nearby.
author: Eva L.

description: Ordered the beef pho (large) @ $11.50 w tax. The soupwas especially tasty with generous portions of meat! I wouldn't know about the authenticity of it but it's definitely one of the better Vietnamese food I have tried.
author: Soon W.

description: Bomb! Seems to always hit the spot. #31 add vegetables and double noodles, I'm hooked.
author: Andrew E.

description:
Cash only.

Pros:

- The owner was really nice and took our order quickly
- Our food was ready in less than 5-10min
- There is plenty of seats, at least 40
- Cheap (~$10 for each entree)
- Large portions

Cons:

- Really cheap, the quality of the meat wasn't the best, especially the meat balls (#27)
- Pork was tasteless
- Bad neighborhood
author: John D.

description: Amazing little spot in the 'loin!  We came in on a very cold day in SF & were immediately impressed with what we saw: tables full of happy eaters with giant steaming bowls of pho.  Seriously, the large bowl is the size of a bucket.  The best part of the ambiance was the owner who yells at you to pick a number about three times in row as he walks over to your table to take your order.  Look, people are definitely not coming in for the charm--which is fine by me.  The pho was one of the best I've ever had!
author: Sarah N.

description: Best bo kho i've had any a long time. I've always had a thing for hu tieu bo kho / pho bo kho and it's always the quality of the stewed beef that makes or breaks it; the beef here has plenty of meat, the broth is strong and the portions are huge! I'm definitely making this my #1 pho spot in the TL.
author: Ryan D.

description:
your standard pho place. can't understand anything the owners say. cash only, pay up front. variety of choices. but let's face it, when you're hungover, you just want a large bowl of rare steak pho.

pretty sure it's the saltiness of the pho (MSG broth!) that prompts you to drink lots of water, thus alleviating the aftereffects of a night out. however, i'd like to think that it's just because pho is magical.

it's great when you're staying in the area and you've been drinking up a storm. but pretty sure i wouldn't drive out of my way to come here. especially since it's in the tenderloin - meaning i get scared (plus it really smells) walking with friends in broad daylight in the blocks directly south and west of it.
author: Yiwen S.

description: Kinda disappointed.  Service was good,  the noodles were just ok.  Nothing special.  The shrimp rice rolls were plentiful but too big. For ten dollars a bowl I expected better.
author: esther h.

description: 6 of us, 2 ordered of egg rolls and it came out to $87 bucks,  NEVER again!
author: Justina S.

description: The chicken noodle soup alone is worth 5 stars on a freezing San Francisco day. I'm assuming there is a fair amount of MSG but who cares it's so good.
author: N A.

description:
Pretty good food, and the service is so quick! I had the BBQ shrimp bun vermicelli and egg roll, and it was filled with delicious lettuce, mint, and tons of rice noodles. I loved the side sauce that accompanied as well!

Although the "cash only" option is a total bummer and water refills are non-existent. I liked this place, but there are definitely better Vietnamese spots in SF.
author: Vanessa H.

description: Not Vietnamese at all. It was Chinese food with Vietnamese names and no Thai tea. We should have walked out right then and there
author: Erica D.

description:
Came here on the recommendation of a friend. Someone said that the pho was too sour but I did not find it so. I found the soup very flavourful and the noodles were well cooked. 

I found it is that each combination was a specific size (I.e you can't choose how big it is)

The spring rolls were terrible though, avoid.
author: Ty Y.

description: Excellent pho! Had the tai (rare steak). Disappointed they didn't offer boba tea- at least I didn't see it. They do use "a little bit" of MSG in the pho. It tasted like more than a bit...the reason for fewer stars is the MSG.
author: Angela B.

description: Had the vermicelli noodles with BBQ pork and imperial rolls.  The service was great and friendly - immediately was seated down!  The rolls were good and vegetables felt fresh.  Have to say this is one of the cleaner Asian restaurants - definitely a plus there.  Would come back!
author: Kevin N.

description:
I'm not much of a pho guy, but my girlfriend loves this stuff and said it was the best she's had (We've been to places in LA and regularly in Chicago). 

While there was nothing special about the ambiance it was clean, which for a pho shop is something I value much much more.  The broth was light and the beef tendon had a great taste and consistency.  Was here on a vacation, but would certainly be back if I were in the area.
author: Tom Q.

description: Best Pho in San Francisco!  I come here as often as I can.  Neighborhood is a little seedy, but on the plus side, there's always parking spots available.  Service is super fast and friendly.  I recommend "26 the dry one, soup on the side" and their beef stew.  Also, their orange juice is fresh squeezed - I always request no added sugar, and their Vietnamese coffee will keep your food coma far, far away (think productivity when you get back to the office).
author: Mandy B.

description: We.went there this morning and.wanted to try the pho soup, it was very tasty, authentic and hit the spot. Service was fast too. I'll be coming back here again!
author: Rico A.

description:
Big bowl is $9.95 on the expensive side but it's a very large portion!   I'm no Pho connoisseur and I'm from NY that being said my review may not make sense for the people who live in LA which has slamming pho all around, but pho me it was slamming!  Clear broth,and a lot of beef parts yum yum!!  This is a win pho me!

Enjoy!
author: Jan Y.

description: Outstanding Pho Ana's large bowl is swimming in beef.  Will definitely be here all week while I am in San Fran. C
author: Theresa H.

description:
Super tasty food. I'm one of the only white guys there. Love it.
* Cash only *
author: Mike V.

description:
3.5 stars

Hubby said we came here for Pho years ago when we were dating, I don't quite remember.  What I noticed is a picture of bun bo hue and hubby said we should go in and try.

The place is pretty big, bright and clean.  We sat at a four top and took a quick look at the menu.  Besides bun bo hue, we also ordered the rare steak dish.

The bun bo hue only came in one size - small but this small is bigger than the large at Ngoc Mai.  Although they don't have banana flower, they did serve with thinly shredded cabbage.  The broth is richer and more flavorful.  The blood cake was perfectly cooked and tasty. It had slices of beef shank and some tendon - all as expected.  They have good chili oil at the table so I get to spice up my own bowl.

The rare steak was delicious.  The thinly sliced rare steak was place over thinly sliced white onion (sweet) and topped with basil, crushed peanuts and fried onion.  Wrapped all the fixings in the rare beef and dunk in the sauce and it's a tasty bite.
author: Gloria H.

description:
Definitely some of the best pho in town. The meat was thinly sliced and tender, while the broth was slightly dark but very flavorful. 

Pretty scary block with lots of unsavory characters walking around.
author: Sven S.

description:
I'm Vietnamese and I tried the foods here twice, my standard is perhaps higher than most Americans.

The Pho is just OK, it's edible but the fat in the soup is just too much. 6/10

The rice plates here are just Okay, I expected much more from a Vietnamese rice plates. The fish sauce isn't right, it doesn't work well with rice. Perhaps they could not make or get a right fish sauce from VN. 6/10
author: Phuong P.

description: Had the rare beef pho. The broth is incredibly rich and flavorful. As a resident of the TL for the past few years, I have made my way through many of the pho establishments and this stand-out place has become my go-to.
author: Monika H.

description: Definitely try this place out if you're looking for a hot, filling bowl of pho! Had a weekend lunch here and had a great experience. Found the service quick and the portions plentiful! Felt very full with just the medium special - can't imagine a large! Broth was very tasty and flavourful, and they didn't skip out on content. I took a chance with the special as I don't always enjoy all the cuts of beef, but the cuts included were very good! If I were to come again I'm sure the pho with my fav cut of meat would be out of this world!
author: Alex P.

description: I just came back from breakfast at Pho Tan Hoa.  I expected some more breakfast-oriented items on the men, but it was all the same for breakfast, lunch, and dinner.  I had a small bowl of pho with rare beef, well-done brisket, and tendon.  My first surprise was the timing.  The food came out within a few minutes of my ordering it.  Next, I noticed the amount of meat in it, which was very generous.  There wasn't much herbs and sprouts to go in it (I'm used to getting a *lot* more), but what there was were good.  The broth was very tasty and strong, which I like.  Some places seem to have watery broth, but not here.  The meat was pretty good, though not great.  Note that they only take cash, but they have a large sign on the door for that, so you can't be surprised once inside.  Paying my check was also very fast.  The staff are very friendly, though there was some difficulty communicating.  I was the only Anglo in there, so maybe they don't have a lot of need for English.  The location is also convenient, just down from my hotel and not far from Market.  I could definitely see going back to Pho Tan Hoa for lunch or dinner, or even for breakfast again.  That was not at all what I'm used to for breakfast, but I really enjoyed it.  My food came to $11 even, $13.50 with tip, so less expensive than a lot of the breakfast alternatives.
author: Bruce S.

description: We came here for our first meal after landing in San Francisco and we are so happy we did! We each got the pho tai (rare sliced beef). The beef was super thinly sliced which is exactly how we like it because the meat is so tender that way. All of the accompaniments (basil, mint,cilantro, etc) were so fresh and delicious. The broth had great flavor without being too oily. My husband said that this was the best pho he's ever had and we've had pho from many different cities so I think it's safe to say we'll be back!
author: Heather A.

description: I came to this place base on the review scored on Yelp. Food was not that great. Definitely not a 4 star review.
author: Karrie W.

description:
Lunch
Pho tai. Pretty gross. Very oily, murky broth. 
Some vermicelli bun. Decent. Fresh veggies and well seasoned meat.
Shrimp spring rolls. Good
$40 for 2 (included tips, drinks)
author: Olivia Q.

description:
"OKAY OKAY YOU WANT NUMBER 41?" This is what the waiter/owner yells at me as he comes to take our order. What? He's right this time! Damn, how does he DO that?  My lunch mates think it's cuz I'm white & not adventurous.  Dammit next time I'm ordering the blood ball soup.  See if he guesses right then! 

The BBQ pork with eggroll on vermicelli was especially delicious yesterday. Check out my photo & see how yummy it looks!
author: Erin S.

description:
Well I can't remember if I ever had Pho or not. It's reminds me too much like Ramen but from what I can tell it was pretty good. 

Now I went it was a Wednesday with very few people in the restaurant. The price wasn't bad at all. 

The only reason I didn't give it a higher rating is because the neighborhood is questionable. As receiving the check takes longer than getting the food.
author: Will I.

description:
(See pics)

Having been here so many times I learned to give ample time to eat here before their 7pm closing time, and continued to see those who ordered takeouts when they knew there's not enough time to sit in.

I learn to appreciate them value their personal life outside of a shop.

There are only a couple Vietnamese noodle shops in this neighborhood and this is a fantastic place especially in a cold rainy evening!
author: T L.

description: This place is one of my favorites in the city. Fast service. AWESOME soups. I always get the beef ball with rare beef on the side which I smother in fresh lime. Then I drown everything in the Pho to let the beef cook along with sprouts, fresh mint and more lime juice. Then grub on it with Hoisin and Siracha all day.
author: Dookie B.

description:
EGG ROLLS - I've had countless varieties at every family gathering. Homemade, catered, in restaurants and these are my favorite. Sadly I could only try 1/2 of one but  I'll be back to order more. You can eat them plain or wrapped in lettuce leaves and sprigs of herbs.

Pho - had potential but too bland 
+ "medium" bowl is really a large. Only one person at our table finished
+ very generous with the meat, more so than almost any restaurant I've been
-  Broth lacked serious seasoning. It was too plain for me and there was a lot of fat. To see that much swimming in my bowl was off-putting.

I'd come back and order a plate of egg rolls for myself and probably try their vermicelli. They can make on hell of an egg roll so l'm optimistic about the other dishes.
author: Audrey N.

description:
guess its not just me that noticed the crazy $$!

I used to come here pretty often with my family, when prices were cheaper and the pho was really yummy. yes they still give lots of meat but the pho broth is lacking justtt a bit. 

came here again recently and its the same. i was starving so everything tasted good. and i finished a medium bowl all by myself. bf's mom says their orange juice is really good, but havent tried it. bf got the com bi thit nuong cha gio, says it was good but rice wasn't that great. 

clean restaurant but pricey! friendly service! still havent found my favorite pho place yet.....
author: Christine M.

description: My boyfriend and I come here whenever we crave pho. They serve a lot of meat, which at other places give very few. You have to separate the rare steak pieces before they get fully cooked in the hot broth or else the pieces will stick together. Other than that the meal is great!
author: Julia P.

description:
This place is the best place for pho! They give a huge portion of meat and noodles so you'll definitely be filled up. Many places give you skimpy meat portions but this place gives you your bang for the buck! 

I've ordered both the beef noodle soup with tripe and rare beef. The soup is flavorful and the noodles are cooked perfectly! The beef is good too. Beef isn't really my forte so I can't really say whether it was out of this world.

My new favorite is the Hu tieu. It is a seafood broth with glass noodles. The noodles and the soup are super delightful and I ALWAYS crave for this. It's the best I've ever had! They give you a little seafood and a little meat but a lot of noodles. I think it's worth it though! 

Each bowl is about $10-$12 but so worth it in my opinion since they give you huge portions! But remember  to bring cash because it's cash only!

The guy seats us right away and also knows when we're ready to take our orders! I'm assuming he's the owner. He's super nice!
author: Marlene H.

description:
Got take-out and had a great experience. Ordered the pho tai and iced coffee with condense milk to go, which was ready for pick-up within 5-10 minutes. All the ingredients of the pho, including the beef, were packed individually for maximum freshness. (A lot of other places lump the raw meat with the noodles, which ends up being a congealed and bloody mess. Yuck.)  They also made the iced coffee quickly after I got there, so it wasn't sitting around and melting.   Definitely did not skimp on meat, even for a small portion.  Owners were super warm and inviting, although a bit rushed because it was height of lunch.  

Will definitely be back.
author: Julie H.

description:
CASH ONLY! Attention cash only,. my co workers and I had to walk around the corner for the ATM machine and pay $6 additional to come try this place out.

Ordered the dry pho my friend recommended all over my facebook and actually understand why they call this place "Hello Hi",. It's cause the owner greets you with a hello,. hi!

The dry pho really is just PHO with the soup on the side.  Half way through my meal, the noodles were a bit difficult to eat cause it was too dry and wouldn't go down my throat.  It felt like a chore to chew and swallow.  I couldn't eat the dry pho any longer and requested them to put in additional soup.  The pho soup/PHO noodle tasted really good, but not good enough for me to take the bus to eat with my co workers again.

I was def expecting a different dry pho experience, but it was obvious because of the dish name.  They also serve BBH and it smelled/looked good. If i ever come back here, I would get the BBH. 

The eggrolls tasted kinda of raw and wasn't as crispy as I'm use too.  Prices were close to $10 a dish.  A bit expensive for vietnamese food I'm use to that range from 5-7 dollars.

The SERVICE was GREAT! and they were very accomadating to our substitutions.  Food came out fast and plenty of metered parking out in front.  Still in the TL,. but also walking distance to and from the bart station .
author: Chanel L.

description:
Great tasty beef pho yummy cha gao egg rolls fast service.

Prices a bit high but it's SF so to be expected. Iced coffee was good but needed more sweet condensed milk. Was busy with plenty of Asian patrons which to me is a good sign of a decent pho restaurant. I was the only white non Asian guy there.

* Cash Only! So don't forget to hit the ATM first.
author: Ben P.

description:
Finally a place that serves bun bo hue the way it is supposed to! I've been eating bun bo hue since I was a kid in San Jose and it is so hard to get it done right and with all the right fixings. This place has the broth done correctly and it comes with the pigs feet, pigs blood and everything else. The large was definitely had A LOT of food so it's not small portions.

The prices I admit are pretty damn steep. I'm assuming it is because of the cost of overhead in SF but almost $10 for pho is pretty crazy if you ask me. They would probably get a lot more people in there to eat if they were just $1 cheaper. There is a decent competition around that area for vietnamese so I don't know why they are expensive. Along with the bun bo hue I got some spring rolls as well. Altogether it was $20. How are appetizers as much as entrees? Anyways, I'll be back but only ordering 1 dish.
author: edward k.

description: Their Bo thai chanh  and pho were perfect. There were other stuff on their menu that I don't see at a lot of viet places like bun bo. Nice old man and good quick service.
author: Kasey H.

description:
This won't be my pho go-to spot but I would get the rare beef pho (and ask for the meat on the side so that I can choose how much to add to my soup) if I were in the area.  Here are my observations:

1)  Plentiful servings.  I got the special beef pho to go which only comes in a large size.  I was given a huge chinese container of noodles and meat, a glad lock bag of bean sprouts and leaves, and a large plastic container of broth.  I could only eat about 1/3rd of the pho before being stuffed.  
2)  Too much meat.  The noodles (which were cooked just right) and broth (which was clean and tasty) were probably the best part of the soup and was overpowered by meat.  I mean, I usually LOVE meat but was sick of it by the time I was done eating.  Also, the special beef pho had a lot of meat parts that I can usually only eat in small quantities (such as tripe) and having such large quantities of it became a bit sickening.  I now stick to the raw beef pho which is smaller in size (although still more than enough for me!) and consists of "less scary" cuts of meat.  If I had a kitchen (which I don't, I'm currently living in a hotel room while my house is being repaired), I would only use what I need into the soup and satay the rest of the meat in another dish for later.
3)  Love the beans/jelly in coconut milk.  Didn't see any oriental grocery stores in the area so was happy to get my fix.  Yum!
author: Linda H.

description:
Non-phony pho...for show.

It gets awfully dicey walking up and down Jones Street in the Tenderloin. But sometimes you have to strap on your bulletproof vest and make your way up that hill to make it to some culinary jewels...Shalimar, Tajine, Dottie's True Blue Cafe...and those are all on the same block. Down one block on the other side of the street is not as polished a jewel, not even a diamond in the rough. Maybe just a nice-looking zircon. It's Pho Hoa...and they do serve authentic pho. I'm no expert, but I have had some good pho in the Hanoi street stands. This comes close to that experience...not quite as fresh-tasting and it's indoors. They have rice plates and such, but why anyone would brave this neighborhood for anything but pho is beyond my capacity for logic?

The service is lightning-quick. I counted about 45 seconds from the time I handed back my menu and the moment I got my serving tray with a bowl of pho and a small plate of bean sprouts and peppers. I ordered the $7.00 beef combo pho (#2), which comes with slices of rare flank steak and some side of a cow I have never seen. It was good, hearty stuff, and the combination of the fresh sprouts in the broth made for a pretty tasty combination. My only complaint...and this is my peccadillo...is that I get easily overwhelmed by stalks of cilantro in my broth, so I had an opportunity to employ my chopstick dexterity to pull out the majority of them.

It's a perfectly clean place, though if you face the window, you get the extra advantage of seeing a lot of strange people pass by....and I don't mean the European tourists. It's too far off the beaten path for them anyway. It's like watching a live performance of "Law and Order: Special Victims Unit"...only with better actors. Pho Hoa is worth a stroll for a quick lunch...just make sure you keep your wits about you as you walk back down Jones.

FOOD --- 3.5 stars...a virtual pho-palooza
AMBIENCE - 2 stars...not the Hanoi Hilton but clean
SERVICE - 3 stars...extra points for their instantaneous service, points off for not coming back with the check 
OVERALL - 3 stars...earn your pho by braving the heart of the Tenderloin...you'll deserve a medal
author: Ed U.

description:
Often hailed as the best pho in San Francisco, Pho Tan Hoa is situated in the sketchiest part of San Francisco on Jones between Ellis and O'Farrell.  Perhaps the location and the restaurant's need for heightened security explains the steep pho prices - $8.50 for just a small bowl.

The pho broth is flavorful and unique in it's own right - it's not as sweet and the color of the broth is much darker than I've had at pho restaurants in the past.  Although I enjoyed my bowl of pho, it doesn't deserves a 30-40% price premium and my risk for personal safety.     

If you are a hardcore pho fanatic, I would recommend checking this place out but please keep your expectations in check.
author: Fei L.

description: I like this place for lunch because their menu had a huge variety besides the standard Vietnamese Beef Noodle Soups. Be forewarned that it is a cash only place. Everything I've tried thus far has good flavor. I would recommend a try even though it is located in the tenderloin.
author: Elaine L.

description:
This was one of the very few pho places open prior to 11am. We tried their beef broth pho (tai bo vien and chin bo vien), and it was okay. Not great, but not very flavorful either. It's also expensive! $8 something for a bowl of pho. Our tab was over $25 for two bowls of pho and 2 drinks. Yikes! 

Not sure if it was because it was early when we came, but the owner was the hostess, server, and the casheir so he seemed very overwhelmed.
author: Alice L.

description:
The noodles here tend to be mushy and the broth is not my favorite. The BBH was not spicy at all and that really bugged me. The portions are big here....I ordered the raw beef dish and it had a mound of meat on it, so that was nice. 

I think Ngoc Mai is much better and since it is in the same neighborhood...I will not be coming back to Pho Tan Hoa.
author: Jenn T.

description: Pho with no frills.
author: Scott M.

description:
The location is sketch and you have to maneuver your way through the crackheads and bums but once you walk in you will be surprised. #1 surprise the place is quite clean and organized. #2 surprise the owner / manager greets and talks to you in a quite eccentric fashion, just reaffirming the Viet accent stereotype with omitted verbs and constant repetition.

Now to the Pho: the bowls here are like US clothing size (a size too big) so if you want small, you get a medium and if you want large, you get a porcelain sink. You can literally bathe a baby in it.  I got the large and somehow manage to finish the whole thing. It was very clean and flavorful. Noodles were el dente and tons of beef. Good deal for $10.50.
author: Ed L.

description:
My favorite SF pho

Here's what does it for me:

+ Lots of meat for carnivores / large portions
+ Their gau is from the point cut of the brisket, my favorite!
+ Opens at 8 for breakfast
+ Decent cha gio
+ Friendly and FAST service.

Could be betters:

+ I like limes as opposed to lemons in the herb plate
+ Ha Nam Ninh broth is better
+ Stay open later than 5 please!
author: Joey D.

description: really high quality meat and soup. no msg. I also got the mixed dried fruit bev/ dessert concoction. it was legit. the BEST part was that the busboy/ waiter, who was hispanic, spoke CHINESE! really excellent service. I'll be back. thanks pho tan hoa!
author: Teresa H.

description:
I come here for lunch at least once/twice a week. Sometimes 4 to cure those long agonizing mornings :p. Service is ridiculously fast! in a rush, I can be in and out in 15 minutes .

Flavorful, thick, dark brown beef broth come piping hot with hearty serving of meats. If you're like me and prefer the taste of bloody steak, order your pho w/beef on the side for leisurely shabu shabuing.

Some parts of TL are teaming with "crazy bums". Luckily there is always street parking right in front of Pho Tan Hoa.

I come here specifically for the beef pho, but everything else on the menu is just as tasty. All n all Great place in the heart of dingy TL.
author: Maggie L.

description:
I stumbled upon Pho Tan Hoa after taking an afternoon stroll in the Tenderloin. After finding their favorable rating on Yelp, I decided to swing by to see if they could rival Them Ky which was only a few blocks away. The interior was a whole in the wall with little décor and ambiance except for the sticky tables, colorful fish tank, and the few people who were sporadically seated here and there. The servers seemed to be on their breaks so the vibe was casual and relaxed. 

I was super hungry and decided to order their biggest bowl of pho which was filled with rare steak, well done flank, tendon and tripe ($9.70). The broth arrived piping hot with slices of beef steak appeared rare red with plenty of thick flank and impressive amount of juicy slippery tendon. I wished there could be more tripe but the massive amount of tendon was quite a welcoming sight. The broth had a good hint of fish sauce with bone marrow nicely intertwined, but the taste of star anise and other essential seasoning were critically held in check. The robust, deepening, and aromatic elements in the broth were slightly better than Pho 2000 but not as stellar as Them Ky. The super high temperature in my bowl rendered swarms of overcooked noodles, and the side plate of complementary basil leaves, sprouts and jalapenos were pretty standard. I was a sweaty happy camper after adding quick mix of siracha, hoisin, and a squeeze of sour lemon to the steamy Titantic.

I also ordered a glass of Che Thap Cam ($2.25) which came with large red beans, jelly, and colored water chestnuts steeped in coconut milk. The drink was refreshing and gave me a nice sweet contrast to my bowl of spicy pho. Service was not the most attentive but my objective of getting my pho fix was met. Quality wise, the price was very high with soup not as flavorful as Them Ky but the thick fat slices of tendon was memorable. Overall, it is still a decent place for pho and one that I wouldn't mind going back to. 3 full stars for the experience.
author: Daniel L.

description:
We came here for lunch and it was a great experience. We had Pho and a rice dish (beef broccoli I believe). The portions were huge, especially Pho, even if you only order the medium size...The amount of beef that I got in my dish was a bit too much for just one person. My friend liked her rice dish a lot and said that it was very flavorful.

It only accepts cash though, but there is an ATM inside the store. The waiter that we had was very friendly and super talkative. Service is really fast, drinks are pretty nice as well.
author: Long H.

description:
I can vouch for Erin S. that the host here is a mind reader and he will shout your order at you.

Walking in the door, he already announced to us that we wanted a "Number 41."  And he was right!  Well, for two out of three of us, that is.  Number 41 is grilled pork over vermicelli with an egg roll.  The pork was lean and flavorful, and the dish came with some crisp fresh veggies and a Vietnamese fried roll (which is much tastier than a Chinese egg roll, I think).  On the side was perhaps the best nam pla sauce I've ever had.  There was quite a bit of chile pepper in it, which made me very happy.

My daughter ordered grilled beef over rice.  She had nearly finished eating it before our noodle dishes came out.  I didn't even get a chance to taste it, she gobbled it up that quickly.  It must have been good.

I loved the food and the service.  The staff take very good care of you here. When you're done eating, don't bother waiting for your bill.  Just go to the counter to pay.  CASH ONLY.
author: Raina S.

description: One of the best vietnamese food i had in the states..ordered the bun bo hue and it even has the authentic pig blood..how can u get better than that..if u are looking for authentic vietnamese food, this is the place to go
author: Chris C.

description:
Had a mostly great experience here. The pho was excellent, and I am a pretty picky pho eater. The portion was huge for the large, and the broth was delicious. I had the large pho tai bo vien. I only had two main issues:

1) closing time: the place closes super early. apparently normally 5pm or 6pm? so almost impossible to eat on most weekdays

2) a bit pricier than other places in tenderloin. $10 for a bowl of pho is on the higher end, but its the city so i understand.

overall, a great alternative for pho if nothing else is available in the city.
author: Thach N.

description:
