I was seekin a Pho place after finishing a multi-day conference at the Hilton Union Square, and was trusting Yelp to find me one nearby.

First, the walk from the Hilton to the restaurant could be a bit scary for the faint of heart. I passed two bums who had each other in a gridlock with one yelling, "Give me back my $8!" I will spare you the graphical details of their facial wounds.

Turned the corner into Jones Street, and everywhere you looked, there were individuals with questionable hygienes -- presumably all homeless or poor. I was expecting to be asked for cash at every step, but was ignored. Oddly enough, I had been passed all week when other pedestrians were begged for cash. Must have been the way I dressed, looked, or walked... *shrug* My point is, the street can give some anxiety to out-of-towners.

Once I reached the restaurant, I was immediately greeted by a man, and a woman behind the cash register smiled. There were 5 Vietnamese and 2 Hispanic guests, and plenty of available seats.

I had read the Yelp reviews and was aware of the portion sizes. So, I ordered a Special Combo pho (Dac Biet), medium size. The man asked whether I wanted large instead. No, thank you. Just medium. Extra meat on the side too please.

Sure enough, the portions were large. I'm glad that I did not order the Large pho.

Service was fast, and the food came out quickly as well.

While eating, I overheard them speak Vietnamese, Cantonese, and English. The man also seemed to know the order of several customers the moment they walked in. That's a good sign -- he remembers what his customers want.

I'd come here again. Careful walking on Jones Street though.
author: Michael Y.

description:
With a hot tip from from fellow Yelper Ray S.  I decided to brave the TL and head over to this pho joint on Jones.


THE PROS:
-I really appreciate the efficient service and MAN, the pho came out lightning quick!
-The restaurant itself is super clean and while we were there, the gentleman was cleaning the whole time inbetween taking/serving orders
-The pho itself was pretty decent, the noodle texture was nice and not overly soft (which i think restaurants tend to do).
- I always order my meat on the side so that the meat doesn't turn chewy and over cooked.  The server gave us an extra small bowl of broth to cook the meat in!  BRAVO!
-They have suong sa hot luu (Tapioca and sweet beans in coconut milk)  It's a dying drink in the Vietnamese restaurant world, so I tend to order it whenever I see it!

THE CONS:
-Nearly $10 for a bowl of pho is a bit on the pricey side, especially if it's not out of this world extraordinary.
-Having to play Frogger with the local people who don't seem to care or not that they're about to collide into you walking in the TL
-Here's a subjective one, but I don't like Pho broth that's too 'clean'.  What I mean is that a home cooked pho broth has a smorgasbord of flavors.  The beef, the onions, the star anise etc.   This broth was very tame and lacked the umph a good broth has.  Don't get me wrong, if you like a nice clean/mild broth then this is your place.  It's just not my cup of broth...tea...you know i mean.

All in all, a decent pho joint in the City.  Clean and quick.
author: Anthony L.

description: This is my go to for beef soup. I'm doubtful that it's without msg or some processed meats but damn it's good.
author: Mark R.

description: Found a cocoon of some kinda of bug on a piece of basil. When I came back the did nothing but give me more bug infested basil. Horrible service and over priced.
author: Quoia G.

description: Great soup. Doesn't taste as MSG filled for the sake of my psyche. Large portions. Tasty. #7 add beef balls.
author: Nelson C.

description: Very tasty Pho with flank steak. Just what my craving needed.  Big pieces of steak and yummy broth.
author: Mina M.

description: Good Pho and Cafe Sua. Pho available in only large size bowls and more expensive than other places, but good. My wife wishes they had smaller bowls, too much for her. Enjoyed their Bun (rice sticks) with fried egg rolls better. We still prefer Turtle Tower in the Tenderloin.
author: Charles C.

description:
Admittedly, I don't have much experience with pho, in general.  My first pho experience was sometime in 2003.  Yet, this is the best beef pho broth that I've tried so far in SF since then.  The small bowl of #15 hit the SPOT after a pretty decent cardio and strength training workout.  

Service was efficient and the restaurant is clean.  

Definitely would go back again, especially with this cold weather!

CASH ONLY!!!  MSG sensitives may decide against trying... Just a warning!
author: Hiromi N.

description:
The impossible occurred over the weekend. My friends and I woke up at 7:30 on a Saturday, bright-eyed and chipper. First order of business: pho. While it felt a little weird to have pho that early in the morning, really, there's no bad time for pho. 

Thanks to the powers of Yelp, we discovered that Pho Tan Hoa opened at 8am. We parked right out front and were pleased to find that we actually weren't the only ones in there. 

The manager/owner/head honcho helped us right away, and I was really impressed by his ability to recite the full dish name when we gave him the menu number. #42? "Chicken soup with egg noodle!" Why yes, that's what I want!

Our dishes came in about five minutes and was tasty, hot and brothy. Came with all the standard fixins. 

It wasn't as dirt cheap as other pho places I've visited in SF or LA, but we ended up paying about $13 each after tip and tax. 

If it wasn't 8 in the morning, I don't think I would have chosen that location just because the neighborhood's pretty scary, and there's something a little disconcerting about enjoying a big hot bowl of pho while staring out the window at what I believe was a food bank or soup kitchen line. 

Otherwise, Pho Tan Hoa came to our rescue on a Saturday morning and kept us happily full for the rest of the day. Thanks Pho Tan Hoa!
author: Christina P.

description:
I decided to come here based on the Yelp reviews.

The food was pretty good. The pho had a nice broth that was flavorful and not too salty,  the meat was tender, the veggies fresh, and the noodles cooked just right. I can't say this was the best pho I've ever had, but it still hit the spot.  

The spring rolls were equally good -- fresh and soft. 

I'd give it 4 stars for the quality of the food, but what pushed it to a 5 was the waitress. I had ordered the appetizer and the large pho. She suggested that I get a half portion of the appetizer (not the full order) because the pho was so large. She was right. I'm giving them an extra star since she was more concerned about me enjoying my food instead of just pushing for a more expensive order.
author: Gil G.

description:
Pho was ok.. But $10 for a pho?! Wth (n this neighborhood has plenty pho spots that are just as good, or maybe better!)

Dry pho was OK...nothing to write home to mom about.... N the reg pho was ok also. 

The rare steak; I got on the side was good. Soft and seemed fresh... (I was very happy with that.. :)
author: Lisa N.

description:
I was pointed to Pho Tan Hoa after Bay to Breakers 2012.  My friend (who was visiting) and I were taking a cab back from Golden Gate Park, and when we asked the Vietnamese cabbie to take us to Pho 2000, he redirected us to Pho Tan Hoa.  "Get the meat on the side," he said.

That was a great day; I've been to Pho Tan Hoa almost once a week ever since.  If I lived closer or they didn't have crazy close-at-somewhere-around-5pm-and-for-some-reason-closed-on-Thursdays hours, I'd be a lot fatter and have very sodium-rich blood.

I order the exact same thing every time I'm there - #7 ("big one," the owner will say) with the meat on the side, Vietnamese iced coffee, and a glass of water.  On a good day, I can finish it all.  And I'm usually the guy asking "... you gonna finish that?"

The pho comes out in like five minutes.  Perfect if you're in a rush.  Or trying to beat closing time.

When my friend came to visit the next year, he specifically asked to return to Pho Tan Hoa.

Here's my comparison list (I eat a lot of pho):
- Pho 2000:  Broth has changed.  I think they watered it down and put more spices to cover it.
- Turtle Tower:  I'm just not as big a fan of chicken pho, and I don't really go for the Northern style of pho.  I know in Vietnam that Northern cuisine is all the rage, but I like what I like!
- Golden Star: This is what people consider the best in the city?  Not a lot of meat, and kinda bland.
- Tin:  Authentically tiny bowl.  Lukewarm broth.  Not very much meat.  If you want good service though, it's probably the best out of the bunch ... but service doesn't add flavor!
- Miss Saigon:  This place has become my second favorite place in the city.  The meat quality is pretty good, though I feel the broth is a bit overly salty, and I end up sweating buckets while I'm in there.  I think the ventilation needs work.
- Ha Nam Ninh:  It's highly rated, but only because everyone goes for that one dry noodle dish.  It is quite good.  But when I went with a friend and ordered it, and he ordered pho, we ended up switching ... because I prefer pho.  I remember the pho being decent, but it taking forever for my food to arrive.
- Hong Kee & Kim:  These guys cut on everything.  Tiny plate of bean sprouts, a mini-sprig of basil, a few slices of meat, and bland broth.  They can get away with charging $9 because it's in the Financial District.
- Pho Express:  I thought this place was okay, probably the best you'll find in FiDi, though my equally-pho-loving friend didn't care for it.  Slightly overcooked noodles.
- Happy Donut:  They have donut in the name.  What was I thinking.  Really bland broth.  Added a boatload of hoisin/Sriracha to compensate.  Also, soggy noodles.
- Perilla:  They don't have pho.  They shouldn't even be on this list.  Also, what's the deal with $12 for garlic noodles with a smidgen of protein?  And everyone loves it??
- Joy Hing:  I went here because I was on my way to Golden Star once and got lazy.  Also because I was on a "let's try something new" kick.  I regretted it fairly quickly.  REALLY salty broth.  And I once ate a big heaping bowl of salt.  (Not really.  Futurama reference.  But the broth is totally salty.)
- Golden Lotus:  Not bad!  They're open later so if I want pho for dinner (always) and am willing to walk through the heart of the TL (not always), I'll come here.  Their portion is smaller and has less meat than Pho Tan Hoa, but otherwise good.
- Four Seasons: Also pretty good pho, and open even later than Golden Lotus, but I'd go to Golden Lotus first if I could.
- PPQ Noodle: A lighter broth (likely of the chicken variety than beef) but overall not bad if that's what you're into.  I do prefer a beefier broth though.
- Kevin's Noodle House: Better than PPQ, so if I find myself in the Sunset again I'll probably go there.  Still not a deep color to the broth though.
- Sai's Restaurant: Their pho isn't really their specialty (though it's perfectly serviceable), the curry soups are a nice change of pace from pho if you're looking for it though.
- Urban Picnic:  Another place catered to the working lunch crowd.  That is, made with speed, not care, and the taste suffers as a result.
- 77 Chinese & Hawaii BBQ:  FiDi quality pho.  no depth to the broth, overly-salted, slightly overcooked noodles, and $11 after tax.  Better than Hong Kee & Kim though; more meat and a regular sized portion of sprouts and basil.

There's my list.  Yeah, there are more places in the city.  Don't worry, I'll get to 'em and update accordingly.  =P
author: Dennis C.

description: Self proclaimed Pho connoisseur here and this is easily the best Pho I had in the San Francisco Bay Area. The broth is so flavorful that for the first time I did not need to add Sriracha or lime to it. My girlfriend had the Pho Kho (or deconstructed pho) and fell in love as well. The prompt and friendly service  is the cherry on top; a real must try for Pho lovers.
author: Michael H.

description: Ordered the vermicelli bbq beef dish. Came to my table pretty quick, the server was very authentic. Reminded me of my friends dad. Big portions to fill you up! The beef was well marinated and the egg rolls were nice and crunchy. Would definitely go back again for some authentic viet cuisine.
author: Eric M.

description:
Tried the Pho here: murky broth, not as clear or as beefy as I'd like. though not too much MSG either. The bowl came with plenty of nicely cooked beef and tendon for $10, garnished with a tiny bit of scallion and cilantro. 

You get a plate of basil, sprouts, jalapeno, and lemon. Noodles were soft. 

Sketchy neighborhood, not sure I'd be back.
author: Derrick V.

description:
This has got to be the best place to eat PHO. My family used to come here all the time when I was younger. When you walk in, there's our favorite, HI -HELLO - HEY person to greet you. You will know what I mean if you go.  They have large portions, great and friendly service and the best pho your tongue will ever touch. Their broth is to die for. Try your best not to drink it all, since its probably not the best for you. In addition, their bowl sizes are much larger than typical Pho sizes so it compensates well for the price differences. It may seem a bit on the pricey side but just ignore it and taste it first! I know you will love it. I brought someone who wasn't too keen on pho and he said it was delicious and the BEST he has ever tried. There was even a return trip the weekend after. Convinced?

ABSOLUTELY amazing.

Wait I forgot to mention the only bad thing: the hobos outside. Since its in the tenderloin, there are alot of strange and daunting people nearby. We always avoided them by parking as close to the restaurant as possible.  Its just another reason to try it out, we were willing to risk everything for a taste of that delectable pho noodle.
author: Sue T.

description:
Hmmmm, wanted  Pho Tan Hoa to be great. .....it was ok, not great, and kinda disappointing. One good thing, got a parking spot right in front .... so I could keep an eye on the chariot (read: stumbling, mumbling, bum-bling is the life style of this 'hood). Although the 'hood does sometimes provide a minor spectacle, like the " lady " that was missing half her teeth, wearing pink hot pants, high heals and was a strutting while carrying  a gold fish is a small plastic tank.  Guess she was takin' her pet for a " walk " on the " street " .

Value equation:   Pricing does not match the food (read: it is out of wack) and the food does not match the hype. While not a penny pincher (read: a few bucks extra doesn't really matter to me) the value equation is important, it is priced too high for what you get.

Service:  Ok, we be in the 'Loin. Lets say the waiter ( ? owner ) has a loud voice ( ever feel like your being screamed at by a waiter ? ) then I remembered we are not here for the ambiance or " charm " . (although charm school would be a life changing experience for the waiter). What the Pho ? 

Food:  Pho' Dac Biet ... well it was OK with lots of ingredients of fairly good quality. Broth darker than it should be (can happen if the broth is more than a day old and re-heated). Priced way too high for the goods.

Bun Cha Gio:  Pork WAY too salty, maybe their strategy since there was very little in the bowl. Cha Gio was OK, not great. Priced way too high for the goods. 

Cafe' Sua Da: good, basic, and helped me get my voice volume to match the waiter.
author: Matsuo U.

description: Prob one of the best soup base in the city. It's really sweet and tasty! Portions are good everyone seemed happy w their food. Only down side was the spring roll and egg roll... Blah!
author: jasmin t.

description:
This place gave my boyfriend food poisoning.  Eater beware. 

I survived unscathed, but my pho tai wasn't very good, too much msg.
author: Le T.

description:
Every time we try to come here, it's always closed. It's not in a good neighborhood so I guess I can understand why it closes by 7pm everyday.

Came here last week with my friend and I'm not sure if it was the food or what but I broke out in cold sweat mid-meal and was about to pass out at the restaurant. Of course he had to take me home before I fainted. Bizarre.

The food was ok. Soup broth was oily and not that interesting. They do give you a LOT of meat tho. Spring rolls were just ok. Not too memorable. My friend also got sick so we thought it was the shrimp in the spring rolls. 

I still like the neighboring pho better. Won't be back here again.
author: Cynthia C.

description:
there are soooo many pho places in the Loin. after a morning of volunteering in the Loin at City Impact, a Christian faith based social program, my 20 plus kids and adults needed some asian comfort food. we were HONGRY. this is an advanced stage of hunger and the need was pleasantly met. not only was the hunger met by quantity (the large pho was really large) but it was met with quality beef broth, perfectly al dente noodles, and plenty of rare beef sliced super thin.
before deciding on this spot, i asked pastor roger who works a block away for a pho spot rec, without hesitation, he pointed me here and not the other ones CLOSER to city impact on jones and eddy.
he without a doubt claimed this place as the BEST in the City.
i am not going to argue with a local on this one.
JYW likes!
author: Jeff W.

description:
This is my alllll time favorite Viet place to go to for Pho!!! Their beef pho is the star but I also love their chicken pho! Light flavorful broths and tender meats. Perfect pho! We always eat here with my significant other's parents! There are always a bunch of other vietnamese people eating there too - that should say something! The chicken pho is my new obsession. Just the right amount of sliced chicken (skin on) without too much fat. Broth and noodles are perfect. 

Small bowls I can finish fine. Medium bowls when I'm starving. Large bowls are always a mistake for me when my eyes are bigger than my stomach. 

Take out is fantastic too! They pack everything neatly and tightly and everything thrown together at home is *almost* just as good as eating it at the restaurant. I love their spring rolls as well! 

Also - cleanest bathroom in a vietnamese restaurant I'VE EVER seen!!!
author: Tracy N.

description: Fast, efficient, in the Tenderloin, Pho nicely spiced and hitting the spot. Generally busy which is never a bad sign. Location not suited for it to be a 'destination' restaurant - great if you live or work close.
author: Eos d.

description:
Iono why the Boy loves Pho so much. I mean he should be loving burgers and baked potatoes. But alas, he loves Pho, which is great for me seeing as it is the food of my peoples. 

I'm from San Jose, land of Vietnamese food. So when I moved up to SF, I found it difficult to find a good Pho place. Until we stumbled upon Pho Tan Hoa. The Pho will make you weak to your knees. Everything tasted great. Even the desserts. The food came out fast and was piping hot. The broth was a deep color and full of flavor.  I'm so happy I've found my Pho spot.
author: Katie Anne N.

description: Consistent and delicious, one of those go-to places for a cheap bite. The service is great, i get the number 41, grilled pork and imperial rolls, a must!
author: Thibaut L.

description:
This is my favorite pho restaurant! I have probably been here at least 50 times. 

The place is pretty big and you can always find a place to sit even during peak hours (lunch time). You may have to sit in the corner. They usually play Vietnamese music.

When you enter, you most likely will be greeted by the owner who is a 40ish Vietnamese guy with an accent. He knows how to speak English, Canto, and also Viet. I don't know what other languages he know. He is also very patient. I  frequently go there with the grandma. She asks a lot of questions and talks to the owner way too much. She also thinks he speaks really good canto but I think most of the time he doesn't really understand her. She also wants hot water instead of hot tea and she wants a separate bowl. Since we've been here a lot, we don't even need to ask for the hot water or the separate bowl for my grandma anymore. They just bring it. 

You can order regular and large. Never tried asking for x-large but they give a lot of food. They never skimp. The food also comes out super fast! You can probably be in and out within 30 minutes.
author: Sarah C.

description:
The Good - Portions are nuts for a pho place, my buddy and I split a Pho Dac Biet and an order of Bun and we didn't really finish either. That's hella crazy for a pho place. It was all pretty decent too!

The Bad - it's like 8 bucks a bowel which is like 40% more than I want to pay for pho. 

The IDunnoFunnyIGuess? - Also the server had no idea what I was saying and I had no idea what he was saying so it led to a good amount of us just sorta looking at each other. yep.
author: Misha T.

description:
How have I not written a review about "hello hi"?!

When I judge pho, I judge it against Pho Tan Hoa. Their pho is one of the best in SF, and their rice plates (dare I say) are the best anywhere. 

As you walk in, there's this guy who always says "Hello hi, how many, come in, come in." Hence the restaurant's nickname "Hello Hi." His accent can be a little distracting, but he's really efficient at getting people seated and taking orders. It's helpful that he always repeats your order back to you to make sure you get exactly what you asked for.

Cash only, so don't bother bringing your credit card.

It's not the greatest of neighborhoods, but definitely worth the trek.

Their spring rolls are generously sized (4 to an order) and are a meal in themselves. The broth served with the rice plates and vermicelli plates are chicken-based, but they will gladly substitute with their beef broth if you ask.
author: Mary M.

description: The meat here is fresh. The basil, bean sprouts, and lemon were fresh. The noodles were overcooked. The broth did not stand out, which can either be a good and bad thing. The drip coffee was great, but the filters a little too old and mishapened because I had grounds in my coffee. The halo halo was pretty delicious, though the straw was too small. The place is relatively clean and the service is fast, which is nothing out of the ordinary. The prices were not cheap. Cash only.
author: Jennifer W.

description: This place is great. Had #12 Rare Beef. Medium bowl was a little too much for me to finish. Nice family wait staff. Place is pretty clean but a little stagnant. But let's be real, you go here for pho, not for the decor. Decent pricing, cash only. Definitely worth checking out. It's legit. I'll be back.
author: Ben R.

description: A typical authentic Vietnamese spot in a really dumpy part of town. I have no idea what the guy that sits you is saying, and I don't care. Feels more like Hanoi that way. Solid portions, solid Pho (that beef broth!), not solid prices. Almost $9 for 4 tiny egg rolls is a bit excessive. ***Cash only*** and not open at night (not that I'd want to be anywhere near Ellis/Jones at night), however a great lunch time spot to grab a bowl.
author: Anthony T.

description:
I felt like a rebel today and ordered the 5 spice chicken here, even though I realize that this is a pho restaurant..

**HUGE MISTAKE!** 

The soup/broth, on the other hand, was pretty tasty.  Lesson learned, and maybe this review will save someone $8.
author: Cora L.

description: Meatball, tendon, rare on side. Rare was VERY thinly sliced (great), tendon a little soft but good and plentiful, Broth was great, dark and complex. Served w/extra small bowl of broth only to get ur bowl back goin at the end. Sawtooth coriander always a plus on herb plate. Loved it.
author: Allen S.

description: Best Pho.  Go get some Chicken Noodle Soup and spring rolls.  You will love it.  This is my standard when comparing Pho.  This place is still the winner.  Staff is great, food is great.
author: Robert H.

description: GREAT food, SCARY neighborhood.  I went at 8:30 a.m. on a SUNDAY, and there was a bum war going on right in front in the street!  its sad because the restaurant is clean, food fantastic, and service pretty good.  My pho tai came out in TWO minutes!  And it was piping hot.  Granted, the restaurant was half empty, but the food was very good, and they give you a whole lotta meat!  I wish they were one block east away from the Tenderloin.  Location is the ONLY thing that makes me hesitate to return.  Otherwise, great food, good service, and clean.
author: Henry L.

description: After a weekend of fine dining, we decided we needed some much needed Asian food! Decided that Pho would be an awesome way to end our trip. Oh man were we disappointed! First,  the location is scary! Homeless everywhere and a really bad area. No wonder they close so early. Walking here was a memorable experience but in a very creepy piss smell kinda way. The Pho was mediocre. Springs rolls were actually decent. Egg rolls were nasty. The Pho in Denver and SoCal is so much better. Tourists should avoid this area.
author: Pom M.

description: Went here for a bite to eat when I was in San fran for a day. The restaurant had good reviews so I thought I'd check it out. The service was really good and fast but the pho dac biet was okay. The broth was mediocre. I've had better. I also tried the shredded pork rolls and I thought there would be noodles but it was only shredded pork and lettuce wrapped in rice paper which was disappointing.
author: Winly N.

description: My measure of a good pho restaurant is how they do the special pho or the "Pho Dac Biet" it has all the meats on the menu in it. I thought this place was very good however what turned me off was the price. I'm used to paying 7-8 dollars for good bowl of pho and that's usually for a large. Because I'm trying the whole "maybe you shouldn't eat until you hate yourself" diet, I was turned off that I paid 10 bucks for a medium size.
author: John B.

description:
The Pho is GOOD GOOD GOOD!

You can choose between small medium and large bowls.  The broth is probably one of the best pho broths I've ever had.  The quality of the brisket, rare meat, tendon and and tripe was excellent and they are very generous with their servings!  A good bowl of pho is worth the trip to the T-Loin.  Pho Tan Hoa has just added one more loyal costumer!
author: Nadiyah S.

description:
When I lived In San Francisco I slurped pho on the regular. Then I moved to DC where there is one (count' em ONE) pho spot in all of the District. So I slurped pho less regularly and had to trek to Virginia to get it. When I landed in New York I thought the regularity of my pho consumption would return. Either all the pho in this city is eluding me, or there are just not that many Vietnamese noodle soup offerings around.

Either way, I feel deprived of only two culinary pleasures in this New York: Mexican food and Vietnamese food.

Naturally, upon landing in San Francisco I immediately started craving pho and burritos. And wanted both. Though not at the same time. Since I was crashing near Union Square, pho ga and cha giao (my staples) were readily available to chase away the previous night's Las Vegas excesses.

Yelpers alerted me to Pho Tan Hoa and I went twice during my 10 day stay. This cash-only pho den is tightly run by an owner with a singsong manner of speaking and a genuine desire to please. It's about as clean as you can expect for a restaurant in the TL and the pho is solid.

When I get the urge to pho on future visits to San Francisco, this is where you'll find me.
author: Miriam W.

description:
3.5 stars. I ordered #13 which is what i get at every pho place for comparison. However, I'm still lookin for a place to compare to #47 at Tank in chicago. Isnt that strange i havent found it yet? 

The beef is tender and good, the noodles are perfectly cooked with good texture. The broth is just ordinary on the lighter side, not a memorable flavor but still refresh. And the meatballs are ok. Still is a solid pho, just not mindblowing. Fast and fresh. Big portion in the size small bowl for a fair price.

Also, the wait staff is suprisingly polite which is unexpected in an asian restaurant.
author: Cecilia T.

description:
I was craving Pho, so I left work and paid for a $10 cab ride to eat here. I've eaten here many times before. I thought I remembered them accepting credit card before, but now they have the 'cash only' sign in the window and at the register. Not uncommon for a Vietnamese place. I casually asked the waiter (the loud, boisterous, generally cheerful guy that's always there), 'so you're cash only, huh?' and he said 'yes'. 

I gave him my order, and he stayed standing at the table. "You pay first.". What? I've never had to pay first before. "You ask if cash only. You pay first or no food". He continued to refuse to put in my order unless I paid first. 

This guy has been in the Tenderloin for too long. I had cash on me, but I wasn' t going to give a penny of it to this jerk. 

Their Pho is not so good that it justifies that type of behavior. Ever.
author: L N.

description: Great Vietnamese place in Little Saigon. The bossman is hilarious and a great host. Food is always fresh. I've been to Vietnam and I can say that this food is authentic. Would recommend for lunch.
author: Luke C.

description: Mmmm...rare steak and tendon was so good!  Delicious steaming broth.  And perfect with the steak on the side!
author: Laura R.

description: Came back here with parents after 15 years so lots have changed.  It is more clean and is still as good as before.  The only reason why it isn't 5 stars is because it's over $10 for a bowl of pho.  I'm not as enamored with the portion size as some of the other Yelpers here are.  Lots of meat yes but not so much noodles.  I can eat a cow so it's a tall task for any restaurant to satisfy my hunger with one bowl/entree.  Cool owner and quite the talker.  Greets people quickly and definitely manages the front well.  Pho came out in a few minutes *super thumbs up* but my last gripe is we didn't get enough condiments and the soup was a bit too salty.  However, it won't stop me from coming back since it's the best pho place in SF.  Sketchy neighborhood but as long as you don't mean mug anyone you'll be fine.
author: Danny M.

description:
This place is good! The bo tai chanh (raw beef) was tasty and pretty decent portion!

The pho here was also good!  I ordered the meat on the side, and they give you good portions also.  

The downside is they seem to close pretty early, but overall yum yum yum!
author: Tramy V.

description:
Great, cheap soup with every part of the animal available, from tripe to tendon to balls (ok, meatballs).  I just wish they had longer hours.  

The guy who takes your order is impossible to understand, but very friendly, so just smile, nod and hope for the best!
author: Quinn S.

description:
All pho is not crated equal.
Most people will agree that there are three things that go into pho: the meat, noodles,and broth.
And it is rare to find a restaurant that does all these qualities well.

I may have found it.

First, it's was a real treat to find such a hearty and filling bowl of pho.
The meal was especially satisfying when considering I was super hungry.

The noodles and meat were better than average, but the broth was what dazzled the taste buds and swayed this yelper: it was rich and flavorful yet still had a light non-oily feel.

By the way, ask for the paper thin raw meat on the side if you don't want gunk floating in your pho (that is if your order comes with raw meat).

I'm giving Pho Tan Hoa 3.5 stars and rounded down because I need another visit to check for their consistency.
author: Dan B.

description: Ordered pho ga and shrimp bun. Huge portions! Flavorful broth. Spicy fish sauce. Mostly non white customers, always a good sign.
author: Shawn L.

description: The broth is decent, but I was impressed by the portions of meat that came with each order.  I've only had PPQ and other Pho off Irving before, but this place was a good experience for the TL.
author: Tim T.

description:
STILL so good! This is my second time review on this place. I still love their pho here, its so damn good. Plus eating here on a windy day in San Fran? Perfect dont you think? I love eating hot pho when its so cold. Anyways, I got the number 32 which was the egg noodle with eggs and chicken and the broth is just super good. The waiter was nice too, i order my extra cilantro and they bring me hella cilantros plus no charge! OH and get the spring rolls! I always hated spring rolls, given ive had a lot of them but never any thats as good as this place, combined it with the sweet sauce.....perfecto!

My only concern is the guy whom whenever you come in, he always says "Hello Hi, come in, come in, come in" with a thick accent and gives you some sort of weird vibe. Anyways, besides that i have no complain for this place. Oh and this place is CASH only...so come prepared! ENJOY the the  pho! You will not regret it:)
author: Cavin T.

description: Best Pho I've had in the city.  Usually very good service, but sometimes it gets a little busy.
author: John W.

description:
Not in the best area of the town, but if you make it to this place you will be satisfied first with food, second with prices.

I ordered the rare steak and brisket pho with basil rolls, everything came out quick, and was so tasty! Loved this place. 

Recommendation:
1. CASH only, and the ATM by the place charges 3.75 per transaction!!!
2. Go there with the group of people, with whom you will be able to share pho because portions are huge! (medium plate I could split with four people)
3. If you go alone, get your ipod -- there is no background music, you will be surrounded by the Vietnamese language.

I paid for my lunch $12, next time I'll go there with 3-4 friends, and I know the bill will be the same :))
author: Anelya S.

description:
I had high expectations for Pho Tan Hoa, pumped up by the positive reviews. I was very pleased with my pho but the high expectations were not realized. Don't get me wrong, this is very good, solid pho, but it wasn't as magical as I had expected.

I had the large combination, which came in a bowl large enough to wash your face in. It was definitely above average, evident in the snappiness in the rice noodles and the quality of the meats and tendon. The meatballs tasted homemade and had a nice texture. Not too hard and not too soft. The rare meat was tender and seemed to have a freshness not found in some of the Sacto pho haunts. The broth was comparable to the ones I've had in Sac. I think my biggest expectation for the broth to be magical, but alas, magic only happens when magic does.

I believe the owner took our order. The service was whimsical, and he sang to us as described in other reviews. I had a hard time understanding him. The pho came out in record time. I was amazed. The owner is super cool because my bro left his sunglasses on the table and as we circled around the block to pick them up, he was standing outside waiting for us with the sunglasses. Now that's service!

The neighborhood is definitely an exciting, never a dull moment kind of place. The percentage of people talking and shouting to themselves is very high, possibly 50%. The crowds lining the streets, and for what purpose I do not know, may pose a challenge to some not familiar with looking tough and walking tall. Walk quickly and carry a big stick. =)
author: Anthony W.

description: Pho Tan Hoa has some of the best Pho in SF. The service isn't amazing as the staff barely  speaks English, but with that being said they didn't mess up on any of our orders and everything was delicious.
author: Lauren W.

description:
Ahhh, I've been craving Pho for a couple of weeks now.  I'm glad I finally found a good Pho place near'sh Union Square.  I'm far from being the most adventurous Pho eater (with all the flank and tendons), so I stuck with the basic beef steak Pho and I thought it was really good.  The beef slices were not too thin and too thick, they were just right.  The broth tasted authentic and not watered down (like other Pho places I've been to).  I ordered a small bowl and it was enough to fill me up, though I do think almost $9 for a small bowl of Pho is a bit pricey.  I'll def be back on those chilly SF days.

The location wasn't as sketchy as I thought it would be from a couple of reviews I read.  It wasn't too deep in the tenderloin.  On a scale of 1 to 5, 5 being really sketchy, I'd give this location a 1.75 to 2.0.  I think it'd be OK for women to go there solo during the day, maybe not so much at night.

Rating:
Beef Pho: 4.5
author: R B.

description: A Vietnamese friend raved about this place. I only went because Pho 2000 on Larkin was closed. The broth tasted like saltwater. There was very little meat in the broth and absolutely no flavor. I won't ever return.
author: Kevin-louis B.

description:
It's worth the trip into the TL. 

Really good pho. Tasty broth, fresh fixins', good meat. I love that you can order a side of rare beef for $3 extra. That's a great value. 

The place was clean, no bugs to speak of. The bathroom was clean too, thank goodness cuz you never know...

The food came out fast and the service was friendly. 

Me likes!
author: Kiristen R.

description: I had guests in from DC over the weekend who wanted good pho before their flight back. Living in the TL there are a ton of places to choose from. We decided to try Pho Tan Hoa and I am so glad that we did! The servings are HUGE. Even the small bowl was more like a large. The broth was fresh and delicious and the space was clean and friendly. This is going to be my go-to pho spot in the city from now on. I personally like it much more than TT and am already craving going back for a second time.
author: Megan Z.

description: I love this place but my mom doesn't. Maybe because everytime I go there with her she has to pay for it. Haha the pho czar is a funny guy. He looks like an old Vietnamese pervert. But this place has good pho when you ask then to split the beef on the side. Ask for cooked bean sprout. It makes the differences.
author: Michael Q.

description:
This is a hidden gem. Close enough to union square but far enough where your average tourist won't venture to. Area/location is a bit unsettled, but not life threatening. Nothing to worry about.

Food is exceptional as far as Vietnamese street food is concern.

Tase really good. Fast service, and adequate presentation.

Price is very reasonable. People are friendly there as well.
author: Albert Y.

description:
This is my go-to pho spot in SF!

The noodles are great and so are the meat.  I come here almost every week on the weekend and this place is always busy! Even though it is, there's usually an empty spot for you and in the rare instances where it's completely full, the turn around is quick and you won't have to wait for more than 5 min.

To recap, great pho, great/quick service, and one satisfied customer.
author: Alex T.

description: I like pho! so much. You should come here if you are sick of american big dish or big Mac.
author: Wendy L.

description:
I think they have one of the best pho in SF (It doesn't mean much ...).  
Of course, I had better pho in Vietnam (Hanoi) also in LA and Long Beach...  but Pho Tan Hoa is good when I get pho craving (I live not too far from there).

I like #13 rare beef and beef boll pho (for some reason a pho restaurant in west LA called Phobulous had same #13 for this dish..) .  Pho Tan Hoa's beef balls are the chunky kind.  Vietnamese beef balls can be chunky or smooth.  I like the smooth one without  tripe in it.  

Even though I didn't see many people doing it in Vietnam, I like to put the chilly sauce and hoisin sauce on the little plate and dip the meet in it.  I got this habit  when I used to go to Pho Hog Long in Long Beach and all the Vietnamese customers there were eating their pho this way...   

I also tried Bun Cha here and they were very fresh and tasty.  Their beef and pork were nicely marinated and grilled.  Their egg rolls and spring rolls were good too.

Bottom Line, there are other good Vietnamese restaurant in SF who serves Bun Cha.  So when I go to Pho Tan Hoa, I eat  #13 Pho.
author: Chie J.

description:
I needed some serious Pho, and we walked down to Pho Hoa to take care of that.  The Pho was very good and I'd eat it again but to be honest, I'm not sure that I want to deal with the walk to get there.  OK, I'm a tourist and maybe I'm just not used to the way things are, but walking for several blocks down streets that smell like piss just isn't the way I like to get in the mood for a meal.  And it's kind of a shame that they close at 7PM.  We walked in at about 6:45, placed our order and were then told that we should eat fast because they want to go home.  I usually inhale Pho and this night was no exception, but it was just a weird experience.  Probably not the best for visitors.

So to sum it up, the Pho was excellent.  Everything else detracted from the experience and turned an amazing bowl of soup into a night that was at best, one that I'd probably not repeat.  It averages out to an okay 3 stars.  My advice to anyone wanting to open another Vietnamese restaurant in San Francisco: Put it somewhere that tourists will go.  Raise the prices at least 50 percent, serve beer and wine, and get to know the local hotel concierges.  If anyone thinks that it adds to the appeal of the restaurant to have your nostrils filled with stale urine or having to walk around the homeless to get there, believe me, I'd be willing to give that up.  In reality, I think it's just that inexpensive food from a culture which is relatively new to the melting pot shows up first where the rents are the most affordable.

Okay, trust me on this, the world is ready for Pho in a setting which is more attractive to tourists, and tourists are willing to pay more to get it.  Dinner for the two of us was an incredible $20 with tax and tip.  As nice as that was, if this place moved down the street and charged us $40 or $50 for the same thing, that would have been okay too,  From reading the comments on this and other similar restaurants, I think some locals would love to see things go upscale a little bit too.
author: Don W.

description:
Who cares if its in the middle of a seriously sketchy neighborhood. 

This is my Sunday afternoon go-to Pho place. 

Their broth is definitely the more flavorful that I've ever had. This place hasn't disappointed me yet, and I've been there twice!
author: Natasha K.

description: Came here on a rainy day with a group for  soup. I had a chicken pho, this was my first pho, didn't really know what I was getting myself into, but I would recommend it, just super messy to eat unless you get a system down.
author: ashley m.

description:
The service here is really good and fast. As far as the pho, it's pretty good. You may request the beef slices on the side and they will supply you with an extra bowl of hot pho soup. This way, you can manage to cook your beef slices to your liking. Since I like mine rare, I enjoy this aspect of this pho restaurant very much. Also, cooking it on the side keeps ur bowl of pho clear from the residual stuff from the 'cooking process'. Other than that, this restaurant's food is pretty decent. Some things to try include: fresh spring rolls, fried egg rolls, pho of course, and grill pork rice plate. 

The ambiance is not there though so lunch spot only and cash only.
author: Eva Y.

description: Best vermicelli in the city!!!! Tons of fresh veggies, herbs and meat. Also their pho is delicious. If I'm not making at home I'm going to pho tan hoa! Best cure for a hangover ever!!!
author: Maria P.

description: Wonderful tasting Pho.  Fresh, clean, with great flavor.  One of the better Pho restaurants in the City.  Highly recommended.
author: Dr. Octagon O.

description:
rude, rude & rude!!!

Let me just start out by saying that I do not expect good service in many Asian places because that is just the status quo, but the lady here was beyond rude. First off, my friend and I ordered the same pho, but somehow mine came out with a bunch of tendon and tripe and no steak and my friend's came out with all steak. I confronted the owner immediately about this and she ran off into the kitchen and came back and yelled at me saying, "Both are the same! Both are the same!" I tried to explain to her, but she CUT ME OFF and repeated, "BOTH ARE THE SAME!" I went up to her later to ask for tea because she forgot to bring it to us earlier, but I didn't even open my mouth and she repeated again, "BOTH ARE THE SAME!" Finally, I told her that I just wanted tea. 

Based purely on the food, the place is only 2/3 stars at best because there is sooo much msg in the soup. With her attitude, it is only a 1 star dining experience.
author: Julie Z.

description: Definitely a good Vietnamese noodle place in town. My family eat here every other weeks. I highly recommend this restaurant if you are here for a bowl of noodle soup.
author: Vicent N.

description:
Food was mediocre. I ordered bun bo hue -- the best part was the bun. Everything is ridiculous overpriced on the menu, especially for a Vietnamese restaurant in the Tenderloin.

I would only go here again as a last resort. Walk 1 block south to Ha Nam Ninh -- waaay better.
author: Larry C.

description: Pho here is better than all other places I ve had. Flavorful broth that is not overpowering. Quick service and quite generous portion. The old man that greeted and served us didnt speak much english but he is so attentive and nice. My table also ordered the grilled pork and rice that everyone liked. They also have fresh squeezed orange juice that goes well with fish sauce-y dish
author: Heidi N.

description:
It's Monday night after a weekend of birthday debauchery. Somehow, someway, whether it be bad food or too much alcohol consumption, I've managed to stay up all night with what feels like the worst stomach flu ever. Cut to the next day where literally, the sound of food sounds wretched....except....EXCEPT...soup. 

The BF came over to take care of me and since I had spent the last 24 hours in my apartment, I desperately needed to get out. We yelped Pho and it came up with Pho Tan Hoa which is a block away from my apartment. It was perfect for what I needed it for. It had broth. It had noodles. It had chicken (chicken pieces were questionable...there were some pretty gnarly chunks in there).

Not sure I'll be banging down the door anytime soon but it served it's purpose and for that, I'm grateful.
author: Julia N.

description:
Went here after reading some Yelp reviews.  The pho was good, but not that much better then vietnam too or bodega bistro in this same area.  Got lemons instead of limes (personal favorite) and they forgot about my iced coffee and waters until we reminded them.  They were very fast with the food even tho the restaurant was full.  A pho was about $7 so a little more than I thought a hole in the wall would be.  So still cheap, but not dirt cheap.  Parking midday wasn't too hard in the area.  Clientele was definitely local vietnamese people, which is always a good sign.  Decor was definitely hole in the wall, so i would probably choose Bodega or Vietnam too if i wasn't in a hurry.

I don't think this is part of the Pho Hoa chain tho.  They didn't have the standard menu of the chain.
author: Aaron W.

description: the guy that runs this place always wears full denim, which I love. and he always remembers my order. the pho is quite good compared to the other places I've been to. and the portions are big.
author: Justin G.

description:
I love coming to this place for my Vietnamese soup noodle fix. My favorite is #12- the rare steak beef noodle soup.  Ask for the rare steak on the side.  It's perfect. They bring out an extra bowl of broth to dip your rare beef slices into so you can choose the perfect doneness..  So good...

This place is never a disappointment except that it closes at 7pm...well, it is the TL so that's probably a smart thing.

All the food is really fresh and the service is helpful and friendly.
author: Heidi L.

description: The reviews are all true. This place was YUMMY! We've been talking about it all day. I've never had a broth I didn't have to doctor up with soy. This was so rich we just added our spicy and enjoyed!
author: Mindie G.

description:
I look forward to Mr. Hello Hi's greeting every Sunday. Pho Tan Hoa frequenters know exactly what I'm talking about.

Like sushi, pho is an addiction I just can't shake. And where better to get my fix than Pho Tan Hoa... Yes there are panhandlers and people who talk to themselves all around the place, but hey, what else do you expect from the TL? I knew from Day 1 that this no-frills clean-scrubbed restaurant and I were destined for each other. 

Items to get? The pho ga (#30) and combination beef pho (#8) of course! Always ask for your rare beef on the side. It's $0.50 more but 50 times more delicious. This place has changed my perspective on pho - I always used to go for the beef but now I am in LOVE with the chicken pho, also known as the most comforting hangover food ever... *cough* Halloween *cough*

Anyway you can't go wrong with this place. The only thing I don't like is how the staff uses Windex when they clean the tables right next to where you're eating. I like my pho Windex-free, thanks... but still 5 stars. I love Pho Tan Hoa. That. Much.
author: Anna H.

description: Still great but still a little pricey. But I made the mistake of branching out to all the other places and after about 6 different spots, I'm back for good. It's just my personal favorite pho broth and noodle style in the area.
author: Kathryn M.

description: Yeah it's a little pricey for pho but trust me the chicken pho has so much flavour! I usually add hoisin sauce, fish sauce and hot sauce but can actually eat it plain! Who cares if they don't speak good English, I never had any problems! My favourite pho place, too bad I moved to alameda! :(
author: Lex K.

description:
Where do you draw the line when price becomes a factor with food, especially in the tenderloin.  Yes..........the new prices are out and they are probably the most expensive hole in the wall Vietnamese restaurant in the bay area.

We came here on Sunday and my God.........when was the last time you saw imperial rolls(4 rolls per order) reaching close to 8.00?  When is a bowl of medium pho running close to 9 dollars?

I love this place but base on price, I just might have to downgrade this place by 1 star.  

I asked Mr. Hello Hi himself, the owner,.............did your rent go up?  cost of food? operating cost?  He simply smiled and said......everything else is going up.  hhahahahaha
author: jason g.

description: Broth...you know that broth thats bright and clear when they set it infront of you but is dark and complex when you're done? Thats what I'm talking about.  Do yourself a favor, walk here from Powell and not Civic Center...it's a tad more pleasant.
author: David S.

description:
mine was a 4 star review before but i cant do this 9 dollar small bowl anymore. I was going here for about 4 years and then saw the prices jump up like the guys on crack outside
, 
i asked the waiter/owner y so exspensive now? and got the craziest smile i've ever seen by him... 

Someone inbox me when this place drops its prices down.......

for now no more hello hi for me

big :(
author: DOM d.

description:
There's a reason it costs just a bit more than other pho places. The small bowl fills me up, and the quality of the meat surpasses some of the other places I frequent. Rare beef and tendons. I ask for the rare beef on the side, and they bring you a separate bowl to cook it in! Pickled lemonade. It's what I order when I've had a rough night with the alcohol. Hot noodle soup and a soothing/refreshing drink. Yum.

The first time, I could not understand a word the server was saying. Sounded like mumbling at first, but during subsequent visits, I started to GET IT. I love that he verifies the order by describing the dish to you, so you make sure you're ordering what you want. Of course, a few times, I was like.. yeah, yeah, that's what I ordered, just bring it, and when it got to the table, it wasn't quite what I'd expected. What I'd really wanted to order was the other dish that he'd described while taking orders... :-/

So yeah, I'm a fan. It's cash only, but there's an ATM at the door. The hours fit most eating schedules...
author: Tinna H.

description:
This is by far the best pho in San Francisco and I have been to a lot of pho restaurants here. Unfortunately they close at 5:45 pm which is too bad if you want to go there for dinner.

The broth is great and the meat is much better than other places.
author: Steve C.

description: Great broth, very tender rare steak and brisket and an absolutely HUGE "large" bowl for a decent price. This was a great stop in my spontaneous SF trip. The only thing I could save negatively is that the neighborhood ain't so great.
author: Alvin C.

description: Some solid pho. The small size is pretty huge, and they give a lot of meat which great. Good prices, even though it's all in cash. Could've done with more leafy greens, but yummy regardless.
author: Deanna L.

description:
If you order pho it comes out in less than 7 minutes - at least, that's how it's been everytime I've gone there. It's good if you're in a hurry. As far as the location, it's not that bad, honestly. If it was further down Jones like Ha Nam Ninh(which seems underrated though equal to if not better than Pho Tan Hoa) or past that then I would be a little more concerned.

As a side note: small group of us(3-4) were the only customers aside from another table of 2 people during one visit and it got a little strange as the owners/employees were hanging out 2 tables behind us and at first we thought they were watching TV or looking outside, but they were watching us eat. The whole time everyone was there. It was a little....awkward. They're nice people though, haha.
author: Susan K.

description: Soooo good! #26 is amazing! You will not go wrong with any beef pho option here. Must try PHO-Tastic!
author: Jenny S.

description: Very good Pho place. It is kind of on the side, you expect the regular kind of Pho. They actually have a lot of options that your typical place does not. "like pigs feet" the broth tastes amazing. blistering hot. the service is typical of pho restaurant . the wow factor here is the PHO, and the fresh great ingredients which has me coming back. everything else is normal.
author: Jeffery H.

description:
This if my first time here since I usually go to Turtle Tower to have my fix of Pho. I only like dark meat chicken, so I did not order the chicken pho here...instead I ordered the beef stew. It was quite delicious. The waiter asked if I wanted more tendon or beef and for some reason I said tendon. I think I should had said half and half. My entire bowl was filed with tendon. I also wanted the thick fun noodles, but I didn't know I had to ask for it. New place for me so I guess next time I will know better. 

I will probably never try the chicken pho there since no dark meat is available. Beef stew w noodles is not bad here.
author: Sandy L.

description:
For my day trip to San Fran I decided to Yelp the best places to get Pho around Chinatown. This place is amazing! It was hard to understand the owner who immediately came over to take our orders, but after ordering our Beef and Chicken Phos and lemonade it took only a few minutes to get our food.

My mom's Beef Pho was very savory, and my Chicken (Pho Ga) was the best I've ever had. I usually get the beef but I decided to give the chicken another chance, and I am very glad I did.

The Pho Ga was just the right saltiness and chicken flavor in the broth, and there were even some kind of roasted onions that made it even more delicious. 
The lemonade was also very tasty, not too tart, not too sweet.

I definitely recommend this place!
author: Abby S.

description: Awesome Pho and awesome service.  Don't skimp.  Get a big bowl.  And a coffee!
author: Joe D.

description:
being vietnamese-american and growing up in little saigon in southern california, it goes without saying, i have had pho and lots of it. 

when i first moved to the city a few short years ago, i embarked on a journey for a great pho restaurant. for months, nothing came close to home. disappointed with bowl after bowl at many pho restaurants that shall all remain nameless, i almost gave up.

then i googled "best pho in san francisco" and found pho tan hoa. 

the menu speaks for itself. if the meat selections span to the next page, you know they are in the business of making pho. just by looking at the broth you already know it's been simmering in oxtail and bone marrow. tasting it only confirms that "YES!!! it's not made from beef bouillon cubes."

i have never had pho anywhere else in the city since pho tan hoa. unless it's after 7pm, because they close that early.
author: Lilly T.

description: Outstanding pho!! Top three in Sf. The broth, holy shit the broth!! If you love pho,, youmust check this place out. So the neighborhood is a little....colorful, its worth dodging crackheads to come here.
author: schmoo l.

description:
I used to love this place when I was younger but they have changed quite 

a bit since. Also it has become somewhat pricier and the broth a bit more bland. It is still decent pho but I have a couple better places up my sleeve.
author: Jackson P.

description:
Located in the wonderful part of town known as the Tenderloin, Pho Tan Hoa fits right into the Vietnamese community. As it was my first time here, I decided to go with the raw beef, noodle in broth combination. Based on prior reviews, I asked for the meat on the side and it was definitely a good choice. I prefer my beef on the undercooked side so this was perfect. The small bowl of broth that they provide is great, so that the meat doesn't "contaminate" with your main bowl. Speaking of broth, I didn't really care for it here. I think too much MSG. The pho itself was alright.

Service was pretty meh. You have to be somewhat aggressive to get your check. Of course, you can always go up to the cashier and pay there. 

This place is pretty decent. Not the worst place in town nor the best. The beef is definitely the highlight for me. Everything else is just standard. CASH ONLY

3 stars.
author: Jonathan L.

description: I had the well done brisket tendon and tripe pho. Initially I came here bc it was open early in the morning. A nice gentleman offered me tea when I arrived. Score. Friendly staff in general. Broth was not thin or thick. Taste wise pretty good. Noodles were firm - half way through I gave up on trying to squeeze-cut them with my chopsticks and instead began to inhale them. Simple interior. Not in the best part of town but if this little Asian girl could walk 3 blocks alone then no biggie. Bill came out to $9.40 inc tax, FYI.
author: Ann R.

description: solid pho, a lot of food!
author: Rebecca C.

description:
Meat on side is .75 extra.

Pretty expensive place actually. 8.50 for 4 summer rolls. 8.85 for a small pho tai.

Rather large for the location. Obviously family run.

Food quality to come

Meat on side is .75 extra.

Pretty expensive place actually. 8.50 for 4 summer rolls. 8.85 for a small pho tai.

Rather large for the location. Obviously family run.

The noodles were too tightly put together and broke apart poorly.

The broth is actually very good! There is depth in it, though it is missing some of the unique flavors of cloves and deep beef that make some stand apart. No black pepper.

The best part of the meal were the goi coun. The fish sauce they served me with it came prespicied. They had mint and fresh veggies inside and the shrimps were tasty.

The pho tai was served with a lot of beef which was nice.

Decent but not super special

Cash only
author: H B.

description:
Consistently good. I have now been here 3 times in the 3 weeks that I have lived in San Francisco. Every time it was amazing.

I actually gave the iced coffee thing a go -- and it was bomb. I am not even a coffee person but I loved it. 

The pho is seriously out of this world, read my other review for more about that, but this review is just to confirm that this place is consistent quality.

While I originally set out with the goal to review a new pho place every two weeks, it's really hard to go out for pho to somewhere other than here. Whenever I do go, I know there's a 99% chance that Pho Tan Hoa will be better than wherever else I go.
author: David H.

description: Quick service, tasty food, and great prices, YAY! It might not be in the best location but I felt very comfortable at this place. Loved all the nice pictures of different dishes displayed throughout both their menus and on the walls - it really helped me to picture what I might like and could order here.
author: Candy L.

description: Their pho may be pricey, but its worth it to me. You get what you pay for. I love it here!
author: TifFancy N.

description: Awesome pho. God, SF asian food is so much better than nyc. Envy.
author: Terry B.

description: This is my favorite pho place in SF. I always get seafood pho anywhere I go, so I can't speak to the beef pho here, but their seafood pho is very good. Broth is clean and good variety of seafood. Slightly pricey considering their location, but it's very tasty.
author: Jane M.

description:
I came here based on Yelp reviews.  I've had a lot of pho, and while this ranked in the top 25% I wouldn't call it tops.  First of all, the portions are MASSIVE (I tried to post a picture of the small versus the large, and the large could feed a small army).  The brisket was a bit tough, but maybe it was an off-day.  The broth could be more flavorful, but it was still an enjoyable bowl.

Pricing isn't bad, though I've had cheaper.  $6.50 for a small, $9 for a large.  Service was very friendly, and they've got enough seating that I wouldn't worry too much about a huge line (not to mention the fact that they close so early they preemptively avoid the huge dinner rush).
author: Misa G.

description:
There's absolutely nothing special-looking about this place, from the outside. In fact, their front door appeared to have been recently shattered, in the dodgy darker hours of a random Wednesday night in San Francisco's Tenderloin district.

However, as I walked past the long line of breakfasting tourists at "Dotties," I recognized the distinctive aroma of star anise scented beef stock wafting up the street.

I had to try some. Very glad I did. Their Pho is just as I like: Rich, perfumed broth, vermicelli-thin, chewy rice noodles, perfectly prepared variety cuts of beef, served with crunchy bean sprouts, basil, sliced jalapeño and lemon wedges.

They also serve KILLER Strong Vietnamese coffee too. Though it's 10-20% more expensive than similar LA Vietnamese locales, it was totally worth it.

You should go. They'll probably have the front door fixed by the time you arrive.
author: Barry B.

description: This place is sticky, dismal and run down. It lies on a sticky, dismal and run-down block of the Tenderloin. That being said, Pho Tan Hoa has the absolute best pho broth in the city. Overall, SF's Vietnamese food is kind of weak compared to what's available in Houston and L.A. This is one of the few spots that really comes correct. There are other places in the city that you might feel more comfortable bringing your grandma to, but if you really dig pho, this is the spot.
author: Chadwick C.

description: AMAZING!!!!!!!!!! Quick service and amazing food!!!! A definite hidden gem!!
author: M D.

description:
Looks like this place has been reviewed to death.

Excellent pho.  Their beef was so fresh, it was just a big glistening pink glob in my food when it arrived.  SO delicious as it cooked in the broth.

The prices were well worth it, comparable to what I pay here in Portland ($6.50 for "small" pho) and the small was about the size of the medium I am used to.

The staff was... um... enthusiastic.  The guy repeated everything three times in broken English and was really in-your-face.  However, considering the hugely international group of people in the neighborhood, I completely understand how he'd want to get down to business ASAP.  The place was packed and the food is outstanding, so who cares if he comes across as brusque?
author: Sean G.

description: This place rocks, the Pho is awesome! I've been coming here off & on for over 6yrs. & it never dissappoints, go there long enough and they know what you usually order when you walk in. good food speedy service, them knowing you, & what you like, PRICELESS!
author: timothy h.

description:
meh.....


thats about the easiest thing i can say about this place.  forget the neighborhood its in, the inside feels like you're in any other neighborhood in sf.  

so that aside, the food and overall feel of the place.  they've got all the regular pho joint familiar things....push cart to bus tables, loud obnoxious old man taking your order, and great condiments at the table with the usual utensils.  


i've been going to golden flower on jackson st for some time now, but recently moved to lower nob hill and figured i'd give this place a shot. 

i ordered the medium 12 (pho tai) and it was mediocre at best.  i like lots of fixins and a good flavorful broth. this had neither.  i added my sprouts, basil, hoisin sauce, siracha, lemon (yes lemon, not lime..... ????) and still....no flavor.  i was confused.  asked for extra white onions since i could barely find any in my bowl...and it made it a little better.  but after a meal for 2 ended up being $30...2 bowls of pho + 1 order crispy egg rolls....before tip???? i definitely won't bother coming back here....

this place falls in the category of underwhelming and overpriced for me.
author: omid a.

description:
Yess!! Very gooood authentic, close to home cookin', yummy pho. The dry pho here is a fan favorite. Served with the beef soup on the side, you can either drink it separately or put it in your dry pho at your liking.
You can also order the regular soup pho here... its very flavorful which I can't say about a lot of pho restaurants. Probably one of the best pho restaurants in the city hands down. Every time I go here with the usual people the waiter remembers our order. I think if your a regular he'll remember you which is nice! gives a nice friendly neighborhood feel.
The food here is also consistent which is very nice! I like to come back here expecting the same thing and getting the same thing every time!

One of my home pho restaurants for sure!!
author: Crystal S.

description:
I dunno why this place gets 4stars. The spring rolls suck! There's like no vermecelli and too much bitter lettuce. And what's with the warm peanut sauce??
I also got the pork egg noodle and it was eh. My gfs five spiced chicken was better though. 
The service is very nice and fast so it might be worth trying other dishes.
author: Mark L.

description:
I've been here a couple of times now and am pretty sure this is the best pho I've had in the city.  Sure I have more places to try, but it's better than Turtle Tower, Bodega Bistro, etc.

I got chicken pho both times and my brother got one of the beef soups and they were all delicious.  Prices are high and I think it's cash only, which sucks, but at least you are getting really good stuff.
author: Joseph N.

description:
This place rocks. The neighborhood is the worst.

Delicious Pho Ga. Southern Style vietnamese food. Sprouts, jalapeno, basil on the side. Delicious chicken broth. Cheap and Fast.

The guy who must run the place talks a lot. He's pretty ridiculous.

Packed during lunch time. Pretty empty after that.

Bring a gun for your walk through the neighborhood to get here...
author: Jamie M.

description:
Not intended to go here for lunch on a rainy Easter Sunday at 11am, but it was better than I expected. You can always rely on Asian restaurants to be opened on religious holidays.  

The service was good. The owner was really friendly. He would explain the item that we wanted to order to us, even though we knew what we would get in our bowls of Pho. I thought that he cared about his customers. 

The soup base was not oily at all, didn't  taste the MSG. Very good, indeed. Even my Vietnamese friend approved it! Lot of meats, meats, meats. The portion was big too. Great value meal!
author: Irene C.

description: The broth is really different and does taste great, but service isn't the best.  Overpriced.  Not sure if I'll get come back.
author: Nancy S.

description: good pho, good prices
author: Long C.

description: The food is a little more expensive than that of other pho restaurants I've been to, but they come in large portions and don't skimp on the meat (though it's sometimes too thick), so it's worth it. The staff is friendly and cheerfully greeted me when I entered, and the place is clean. I wish the restaurant wouldn't close so early so I can have dinner here, but oh well. If you can stand navigating through the questionable neighborhood, this place is worth a visit.
author: Esther C.

description:
best pho i've found in SF.  Really good vermicelli noddle dishes also and the best part is there are vietnamese people that work there and eat there.  That's got to be a good sign, right?
So the only downsides are that 1) it's not terribly cheap relative to normal Pho prices.. around $8 for a large bowl ... but honestly, it's really cheap for good SF food.   2) hard to park  3) they close at 7pm!?!?    Overall, good value and REALLY yummy Pho.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
Definitely not worth the price. Quality of meat was awful and the service made the food taste even worse. Witnessed owner being racists towards a potential customer just cause he was black. Poor guy was just looking for soup for his sick wife. 

Definitely would not go back and unless you like paying an extra $2.00 for below average pho, I suggest you don't go there either.
author: Y L.

description:
The first rule of a good pho place is that somewhere in the name should be the word, pho. The second rule is that along with the bowl of soup, there should be lots -- huge, plentiful and overflowing -- accompaniments of fresh herbs, bean sprouts and condiments.

Pho Tan Hoa followed both rules and, on days when its meat supply is fresh, can compete as the best pho joint in the San Francisco area.  There are better places in San Jose, but if you want to stay in SF, this is the place to go.  Just steer clear of the crackheads in the Tenderloin.

Full review on my site.
author: Josh N.

description: I've tried multiple Pho soup restaurants in the area and this is the one that puts "love" in their broth. They were friendly and the basil was large and fresh.
author: Vito G.

description:
Large bowl, fried & fresh rolls are good!!! U have to wrap the fried roll w/ lettuce & mint leaf then dip in sauce...it's good.  
The beef stew with rice or bread is good too.
author: Mark H.

description:
Pho Tan Hoa excels at beef pho.  Their broth is beefy (duh) and doesn't leave you parched.  Their meat is tender too, regardless if you order it on the side or not ($.50 extra for raw meat on the side).

They also have an interesting item that I've never had elsewhere.  But thanks to my pho expert of a brother Brian P., he introduced me to their Pho Kho.  This is pretty much a soup-less bowl of pho, but the noodles have been mixed in a sesame oil and fish sauce concoction.  Sounds weird?  Trust me, it's tasty.  Broth comes on the side for your slurping pleasure.

The space at Pho Tan Hoa is larger than most pho joints in the TL.  The restaurant is pretty clean and most importantly, the chopsticks and spoons at the table are clean.  The menu prices aren't the cheapest though.  The view you get with a window seat is priceless too.  You'll witness drug deals going down, junkies shooting up, pimps waving their dollar bills, you see it all.  

Ahhhhh...the best of the best of the Tenderloin can be had at Pho Tan Hoa.
author: Diane L.

description: Pho was awesome! Spicy, herby, aromatic. Tendons, meatballs, brisket and rare beef. Winner!! As the host is a trip. It in the Tenderloin area and there isn't anything tender about that area
author: Eddy S.

description: The large bowl of pho here is actually an extra large bowl of pho by most other pho restaurant standards, so ordering a medium-sized bowl will likely satisfy you just fine. The large bowl will often run you less than $9 with tax included. A good deal for pretty good pho, pho-realz! Just wish they stayed open a few hours longer as they pretty much begin closing up shop at 6:45 p.m.
author: Erich D.

description:
I did my homework and I read all the right reviews from other Vietnamese yelpers but still I was very disappointed.  I know everyone is comparing this place to true Pho places in Hanoi and LA but I'm just going to be fair by comparing it to Pho Hoa Hiep in the sunset and it still gets a solid two.  Let's see here, the pho,ie the noodles, came in a big mushy clump, the meat and meat by products were plentiful but lack any flavor.  The broth was so laced in MSG I couldn't stand to taste my own breath for most of the day after this meal.

To be quite fair I would like to add that I'm not a big fan of Saigon Sandwiches which most people love.  If you like Saigon Sandwiches you'll probably like Pho Hoa Tien as well because they do not skimp on meat.
author: Amber L.

description:
I like tendons. In fact, it is the one vital ingredient for me when eating pho, while everything else is secondary. So when I was served a steaming bowl of pho with plenty of large, tender, slightly bloody tendons, I knew I was in for a real treat.

It didn't hurt that everything else was really delicious too. The broth was nice and flavorful, the meat good (not overcooked) and even the tripe was tasty. And oh, those tendons.. MMM.

I also like how our server was taking the initiative and happily telling us about what we were ordering. I couldn't understand him and tried my best to, but it was very endearing. I hope he doesn't get discouraged from trying!
author: Ryan V.

description: Been coming here for years since it's a short walk from my apartment.  Very good pho, nice friendly service, but on the downside they keep on jacking up the prices and I'm starting to feel a bit nervous carrying all that cash in this neighborhood.
author: Nosniv X.

description:
I went to this place for lunch today and totally had the runs afterwards.

There was a nice portion size of meat, but the broth was cloudy. They did offer fresh thai basil, which was the highlight of my dish. Otherwise, they offered lemon instead of lime (the lemon was not freshly cut) and bean sprouts that were too old--they were hardly crispy anymore and the beans had all fallen off.

The broth could have been brightened up a bit more by more fresh cilantro or mint (the only cilantro had been in the soup already when it came on the table).

The noodles were too thin for my taste and falling apart 20 minutes into the meal, which was a shame.

The service is excellent and super fast.
author: Bootylicious J.

description: My BF got the real bad food poisoning here.  Uh-oh.  Poor him on the 45-minute  BART ride back to Dublin.  I ate too and felt ok.  We'll stay away for now but no promises that we won't be back one day since this place is his TL favorite.
author: Holly B.

description:
Simple, clean a delicious Pho soups !
You can go there with no hesitation is you're a fan of Vietnamese Pho soups.
author: Tristan L.

description:
The beef pho here is hands down the best I've ever had. The broth is perfectly flavored, meat is delicious, noodles have great texture and there are plenty of basil and sprouts. A small is still pretty big.  I have never finished a bowl of pho until I ate here.  I just could not stop, even though I knew I'd have to ride my bike afterward.  Let me tell you, that was one uncomfortable bike ride with a bulging belly full of pho.  Still, no regrets.  

My only beef (get it??!) with this place is that they close at 7 pm, which makes it tough for me to get there in time. One star off for that, because I want to eat here more, and for that to happen I need there to be more Pho Tan Hoa hours in my day.
author: Katie M.

description: Just arrived here before they closed. Anyway, yummy pho. Hearty serving size for large. Lots of meat and noodles. Soup is great. Nothing to complain about here. Well worth the money. Yes it's in the TL, but use some common sense when walking around the area. If it closer to work distance wise (like Green Papaya or Tu Lan, I would definitely choose this place over those two to get lunch.
author: Gerard Y.

description: One of the better spots for beef pho around. Solid.
author: Guillermo K.

description:
Cheap, serves you lots of meat, gives you an extra small bowl of soup, tasty noodles, tasty flavor.

Unlike the other pho places I've tried around the area, this one is the only one that serves it the way I"m used to (with flat, thin slices of steak on the side instead of little chunks of meat).
author: Angela H.

description: I had been craving for a good bowl of PHO for many months. Finally, i found this place in walking distance from my GF's apt. Seeing the review in yelp i was very excited to go to this place. The bowl of pho i got was pretty huge (Large :) ). The broth was decent and the overall dish was good (Had better). My GF had five spice chicken which was honestly awful. Overall a decent place to eat pho but they need to start offering some sizes.
author: Anuj K.

description: Yum!  Ask for extra veggies in your Chicken Pho......fresh brocolli and bok choy, and extra herbs.....fresh spearmint, cilantro and basil.  Very friendly, clean and tasty broth.
author: Jeanne F.

description:
"HELLO HI!" 
thats all. eat here. its pretty good. 
(lol. im just kidding)

you probably didnt get that unless you've been here. anyway, the food is pretty good. you'll like it. a lot of people come here for the dry pho. its really good with the hot sauce (not the siracha, the other one that you have to scoop).  the guy that takes your order seems slightly rude but he doesnt mean to be at all. he's hilarious.
author: Linh P.

description:
Growing up in NYC I had really good pho, and even better when I traveled throughout Vietnam for a month. Living here in the city for the last five years with a larger vietnamese population than NYC, I thought I would be able to find the right combination in a bowl of pho: tasty beef broth, noodles cooked al dente, more than 3 different pho options, two bowl size options, and affordable. 

The vietnamese in me was ecstatic to finally find such a place called Pho Tan Hoa. They def have a larger variety of pho options than I have seen in other vietnamese restaurants in the city. I appreciate large portions and was excited to order the large Pho Tai Bo Vien (rare steak with beef balls) and found it to be a huge ass meal on its own. Though I was sad to see only two beef balls (I think one ball was cut in two) floating helplessly, the flavor of the broth, the proportion of beef and noodles, and the amount of thai basil I crushed in the broth made it just right.
