In my last visit to this joint, I was entertained by the 15-minute conversation the servers had in vietnamese about the weather while watching the news. These conversations, and especially the food, will make me a regular.
author: Nancy B.

description: the only place in sf that i can find with good chili oil! and the size of the small is so huge! love it
author: Sara N.

description:
Gah! I really hate reviewing my favorite joints 'cos I'm afraid they'll get too busy for me to love. I'm selfish I know....

I always order the same damned thing, so I can't give a full 5 stars till I've tried the entire menu. The amazing special combination pho (rare beef, brisket, tendon and tripe) is to die for! Moreso than the broth, the tendon is to die.... It's been a long time since I've had nice portions of melting tendon all made better by sucking up the broth. I'm somehow transported to eating my grandmother's oxtail soup, back in the day.

I accompany this with the fried eggs rolls, served with lettuce and herbs. It's a bit too much food for the soup, but I can't help but have a bite. The egg roll is a tad bit on the greasy side, and it's pretty standard, but coupled with the fresh veg, and the yummy dipping sauce, it elevates the egg rolls to another level.

Iced coffee here is stroooooong, sweet and delicious! I love the owner. He's bossy, and tells you what you're going to get, and I shut up like a good girl and take it!
author: Antoi C.

description:
Finally, a solid pho place. It's on the expensive side at $6.50 for a small bowl, but the small bowl is freakin' huge--we're talking bigger than my lollipop head. 

The broth was clear, flavorful, savory. The noodles weren't lumped together in a ball. There was plenty of beef and the meatballs were tasty. I couldn't finish my pho despite how yummy it was, but I'll be back--pho shizzle.

Others had the Com Thit Bi Cha (rice with BBQ beef, shredded pork, and egg quiche) and the Hu Tieu Do Bien (seafood chow fun). Both looked pretty delectable. You can't really go wrong here with the pho, portion, and price.
author: Liz T.

description:
I eat noodles when I am happy, I eat them when I am sad, I even eat them when I am on vacation.  Would you believe it if I told you that I somehow found my way to china town in Paris without knowing a lick of french just to satisfy my noodle cravings.  Maybe it's some kind of noodle mojo that I've inherited from my parents as they aways seem to know where the asian places are in any city.

On a recent visit to SF we stumbled across this noodle house two blocks from our hotel.   It never ceases to amaze me how quickly the scene changes from block to block in urban cities.  One moment we are basking in the golden sun near ritzy Union Square and the next minute after a couple of turns we are literally smack dab in the grimy hood.  Not a bad thing since decent viet food usually thrives in these surroundings.

It was 7:50 AM when we peered into this shop and the owner was cordially waving us in.  He said that they didn't open until 8 AM but he proceeded to seat us anyways.   Their trough sized pho xe lua (XL bowl), which was delivered to our table at lightening speed, could have easily feed all four of us.  The broth is comparable to what we get in southern california and as such had just as much msg in it as well.  No filet mignon here, but the meats were well prepared and the greens were plentiful.  By 8:15, the locals were packing in plenty.  In truth the pho here is probably only a 3.5 compared to Little Saigon, but the simple fact that I can have a decent bowl of pho on a Saturday morning hundreds of miles from home is priceless.

We also ventured outside of the noodle confines and found the rice dishes palatable as well.  Their com suon nuong (pork chop rice) was v.tasty.  The meat was grilled just enough to char the edges without drying.  I believe it was com tam (broken rice) that was used, but I could be wrong as my memory tends to be fuzzy in these early morning hours.  

Entrees and noodles range from 5 - 8 bucks so the prices here are very forgiving on the pocket book. 

Overall, I think this place deserves a visit by locals and visitors alike who would like to sample vietnamese street food in a casual atmosphere.  Just be prepared for the brisk service and drab surroundings.
author: Anh N.

description:
Just picked up some take out from this place.  I ordered a Pho Ga and a Pho Tai Nam.  Both were good, but I've had better.  Each cost $8, which is on the pricier side.   Really bummed that I forgot to put in the rare slices of beef before I finished the rest of the bowl.  Too hungry to think ... just dove in and powered through the Pho Tai Nam w/ no Tai.  I'll see if I'm inspired to cook it up later ... it's a shame because it's probably 1/3 of a pound.

I prefer Pho 2000 over this place, but 2000 was closed today (Tues).  I would likely return here for another experience, but I don't think I'm going to get cravings for this place.  

Solid and good place, just nothing to rave about.
author: Rod C.

description:
Been wanting to try this place for a long while and when my try at Brenda's Soul Food was going to be denied (Long Wait on a Saturday Afternoon), we had to make alternative plans and so Pho Tan Hoa did the trick since it was somewhere I've been wanting to try for awhile and was in the same general vicinity.  

Quick Service, food brought to you in an instance and really good broth.  This is definitely going to make it into my Pho rotation but probably not in Tier 1 since it is not that close to home.  

The waiter (possibly owner) was kinda cool too cause when he repeats your order, it sounds like he is an auctioneer.  So everytime he finished taking orders at all the other tables, we kept hearing him repeat the orders and I would just have this smile inside like I was at an auction.  

They also gave alot of meat so the value is certainly there as well.....  The only thing is, there were definitely more "street" people in this area than some other places so be ready for that if you are not the type of person used to that....  Sometimes, it makes for a more interesting dining experience as you eat your Pho, gaze out the window and enjoy a Free Show.....
author: Mark W.

description:
Really good pho here. I always order the rare steak, beef brisket pho and it never fails to satisfy me. The area is sketchy, right in the heart of the TL. If you're up for some entertainment, be sure to request the tables by the window and you'll be able to watch some "transactions" going on, maybe even witness how crack is smoked and the consequences of it. It's like, dinner and a show (COPS in SF LIVE)!

Other than that, the service is really QUICK and I mean quick because if you can't figure out what to order, the owner will try to read your mind and figure out what you want to order. It's okay though, if you request more time, he'll give it to you. Once you order, your food is at your table in less than 10 minutes. Definitely a good spot for a quick, filling meal.

Not recommended for first dates.
author: Zell C.

description:
"I Like You Pho"

Good Pho. Very reasonably priced. This place full's you up on just a few dollars. It is very true that this place has no decor, the music playing exhausted me, it was MIDI type music. The owner/ waiter is a cool cat, nice heavy accent I didn't understand but two words he said. Now regarding Service, What service? LOL... but hey if you walked into a place liked this you came to eat and nothing else.
author: Reyna D.

description: Not fancy, but they have really good pho. Their coconut drink is also good. Portion size is massive too. Would recommend.
author: Jason L.

description:
Huge, gigantic, thick, slices of quivering tendon.  Yes.  I want it.  And yes, it's hard to find in the city that wants to slice it up thin and mix it in to the soup so that most of it dissolves.  Here, the tendon delivered.  I will have a special place in my heart for this place because of the tendon.

Now that the pleasantries are over and we know each other better, let's talk about the real stuff.  First, I get the beef on the side.  Fine.  They charge me for it.  Ok.  But then they give me slices of beef that are thick, a small bowl of soup that was lukewarm, resulting in raw-though-soaking slices of beef-so-rare that even I am afraid of Mad Cow.  My main bowl ended up cloudier than the small broth bowl for cooking.  Not good.

The other thing is that the iced coffee was also really really small.  To make it look more qualified, they should have just used smaller cups.  The big, half empty cup (including ice and coffee) just emphasized how little beverage was served.  

The spring rolls were unspectacular.  Nothing unique or notable at all.  The wrapper looked like ordinary spring roll wrapper.  The filling was not particularly meaty nor flavorful.  The lettuce was very small and there was no noodle to include with the mint and lettuce.  

The broth was clear and a lovely caramel color.  However, not very hot.  And they didn't have any fish sauce at the table.  Were it not for the tendon, I would not have had a good lunch.  I'm already having a bad life, can't I get a good lunch?  Is that too much to ask?

**Updated, 1 hour later**
I was aware where the other people forewarned me about the MSG.  I just woke up from an hour and a half nap.  Not really sure what took me down, MSG or upcoming finals.  I shall try this place again after July and then I will know.  Also, this place did not have the best ventilation and I get very warm when eating hot soup.
author: Christina C.

description:
Can happiness be filled in a soup noodle?

The answer to that is YES!

This place takes me back to the San Lorenzo High school pho runs that my buddies and I did for our 40 mins lunch break. 

600 cents get you a "small" pho.., but the small is not SMALL like Turtle Tower small.. but a huge amount of pho. My SO and I went here and she said that you will be presented with a LOT of food...  I can't imagine how much food a LARGE pho will be..

the pho was tasty, a bit too much MSG, but they gave a lot of noodles, a lot of beef, flank, and tripe... 

For $6, you can't beat it.. it's too bad the neighborhood is dingy, but it's not THAT bad as other Yelp members make it.
author: Wilson L.

description:
Gather round kidlets whilst your fairy Jill-mother tells you the story of Goldilocks and the Three Phos.
And it goes a lil' sumthin' like thiiiiiis:

One lone lower nob girl I be
all by myself I gots one roomie
The sun is shinin' down on our way to Pride
Our bellies is rumblin' cuz they gots nuttin' inside
Goin for fair food we ran into Pho Tan Hoa
My roomie said you down?
I said you must not KNOW!
He talked of yummy pho
that came in small, medium, large
I said let's get some yo' you're in charge!
He ordered a large number seven 
minus tendon and tripe
I ordered a small of the same without dat gripe
Da pho was off the hizzy
The size I got was perfec' fa sheezy
My roomie got hella ill
Had ta take a Pepcid pill
So yo' I'm Jill S. an if you want respec'
Order a small pho n' keep your appetite in check.
author: Jill D.

description:
When they say raw, they mean raw... this is only the second Pho place I've been to in the city, and I have to say... nice job. Bloody pink and thinly cut, my #16 Pho was covered in raw flank steak with a few peeping numbers of expertly cooked, super soft tendon. The broth was so tasty, and it didn't leave that normal after taste or numbing sensation that I've had at other Pho places. Portions are huge; I know that Pho is normally pretty well portioned but... man a small here is a large in the South Bay.
Good stuff, would come back here when craving Pho in the city.
author: Jessica L.

description:
Would like to give a 3.5 star, really. Rounding down for sketchiness of the location...

One of the better places to get Pho in SF. The portions are huge. The broth is pretty good, and the price is right. Parking isn't too hard to find, though the denizens of the Tenderloin can sometimes give you problems if you come here.

Extra half star for the owner who asks for your order like the guy from the Micro Machines commercials.

Recommendations:
- Get the Pho Tai, meat on the side. A medium is enough to fill me up.
- I like the fried spring rolls.
- The meatballs aren't the best I ever had, but it was still pretty good.
author: Rondeep C.

description: Best Pho in Cali yet...I had the Chicken Pho......fresh brocolli and bok choy, and I asked for extra herbs.....fresh spearmint, cilantro and basil were delivered.  Very friendly, clean and great broth.  Go for the food not the Ambiance
author: Alex S.

description:
This place IS the best pho in SF.  

Don't make me throw the race card down on ya'll.

I've become a bit distrustful of yelp reviews as every other Pho house gets 4 stars... and there's no way anyone comes close.
author: suckafree c.

description: I ordered the pho with brisket. The pho and broth was very good, but the meat was VERY fatty... I mean, I probably put 3/4 of my "beef" on the side plate cause it was all fat.  Would've been four stars if that didn't happen.  The service was prompt but kind of stern.  Also, this place only takes cash!
author: Chich S.

description:
Plenty decent Pho, but not the best in the city. 

Broth was tasty but laden with garlic and MSG.  Neighborhood is definitely questionable -- we're in the TL here.

One step nicer and fancier than base-level pho -- some attempt at decor, not hospital emergency room bright -- at base level prices.

Music selection?  Sappy Vietnamese pop music and Muzak covers of 70s American pop songs.  Must be a satellite channel for this stuff because you hear it all over town.

Recommended for: very local residents, intrepid Union Square tourists who want the best pho within an easy walk and aren't afraid of street people and drug dealers.
author: Gil S.

description: I stopped by here on a Sunday afternoon at about 3.30pm, there was an awful lot of "local color", the restaurant itself was pretty quiet with just a family eating in there. I ordered the rare steak and brisket, and it showed up a few minutes later, wonderfully hot. The thai basil and bean sprouts on the side were nice and fresh, and the noodles, broth and meat were exactly as you would expect. I could have used some more noodles, but overall it was a wonderful soup. I think the total bill came to about $10 that was for the pho and some lemonade. They had "salty lemonade" on the menu which I haven't tried before but may well next time :-)
author: Karl L.

description:
Fast service, large portions, and all the essential condiments/accompaniments (bean sprouts, basil, siracha, lemon, jalapeno, hoisin sauce) for pho are always provided. 

BUT, I think they use wayyyyyy too much MSG. And I don't like the pork they use for the dry vermicelli noodles or the rice plate. Its really dry.
author: Dorothy N.

description:
The pho is just alright. Maybe I was just turned off by the $7.35 price for a small bowl of pho. The only reason why this place gets even a 3 star is that the service is pretty good and it's open at 8AM, which was perfect for my hung over friend. 

I went to this place when I first moved here in July 2007 and the cost for a small bowl was $5.70 or something like that. What's the $2 increase! I will only return here if we are in need of an early morning Sunday meal.
author: Katherine F.

description:
The best Pho in town. Get the rare beef on the side so it doesn't cool off the main bowl (they bring you a separate bowl of broth for the beef). Seafood noodles, Barbeque beef and fried Egg Rolls with noodles, and the Beef stew are my favs. Mostly locals that eat here. This place is not part of the 'Pho Hoa' chain.  
This is a pretty dicey part of the Tenderloin, so if you're a tourist, don't look around like you're scared to death, even though you are, and please don't look like a target.
author: Arlene C.

description:
Also known as, Hello Hi. Walk in and you'll understand.

Dry noodle pho. Pretty good. All the fixings in a pho but dry and some kind of special sauce. Soup on the side. Steak on the side.

Every time you ask for steak on the side, you get another bowl of soup just to dip the meat so it doesn't get in the soup you are eating. Good thinking.

Even though the dry noodle pho is good, I still prefer my massive bowl of meat, noodles and broth.

Good times.
author: Jimmy N.

description: Been going to this place for over 15 years. I don't have to order, the guy remembers what I order. #7 large with beef on the side.  The prices have jumped up the last couple years. You get a lot of noodles, and a lot of meat. The broth is a little on the darker side. Sometimes my beef on the side is still a little frozen. But the broth and noodles are consistent. The banh mi bho kho ( bread and beef stew) is good here. Just ask to have the bread toasted. Don't worry about the neighborhood, nobody is going to mess with you unless you're asking to be messed with. I just go strictly for the pho now, haven't had a rice plate here in years.  If you do get beef on the side ask for extra lemon, squirt the lemon on the raw beef mix it up with your chopsticks then throw a little black pepper and a dash of fish sauce. Let it sit for a minute and its good to go. You can dip the raw meat in the side bowl of broth they give you if you like but that defeats the purpose of getting raw beef on the side.
author: P P.

description: 3.5 stars.  Pretty decent pho with good portions of meat.  Also had the BBQ pork, which was too salty and overcooked/tough.  CASH ONLY.  Clean place without smelling like Pho when you leave.  Nice.  Kinda expensive for location.  (i mean, c'mon, I risked my life, climbed over piles of dog dung, and the occasional puddle of urine on the street to get to your restaurant....)
author: Marcus K.

description: Very clean. Excellent food. Nice people! We are visiting from LA and absolutely love this place and have eaten there twice already!! Tomorrow a third time. The prices are also very reasonable. I wish Santa Monica had a place like this.
author: Rob N.

description:
Pros: Great food.  The chicken po was good, the soup tasty.  We got egg rolls which are ordinarily pretty boring at most restaurants.  They were hot and tasty here and served with huge mint leaves.  I've never tried egg rolls with mint but they go surprisingly well together and I recommend you trying them next time.

Cons:  The neighborhood is sketchy and the restaurant is a bit grim inside.  This is the sort of place you go for good food but not for a romantic date.  We arrived around 6:45 and they told us they were closing soon (7:00) but that we could stay until 7:15.  The whole meal was rushed and I felt like the people there were waiting around for us to finish so they could sweep our dishes away and see us out the door.  Stepping out the front door though it was understandable why they too wanted to be out of the area before the sun set.  

Bring a friend and leave before dark, but the food is worth walking through the colorful inhabitants of this area of the city.
author: Megan L.

description:
The pho is here is pure bliss.
They have all the combinations of pho possible... even create your own.
They open at 8:00 am for those early morning pho cravings.
I normally get a small, which is plenty... eat it up fast!
Cash Only!
Caveat: High MSG content. If your system is sensitive to MSG, don't come here. The Pho is good, but MSG sucks.
No wonder I drink a ton of water during my meals
author: Geordie E.

description:
My favorite pho spot in the city! I usually never get beef pho, but this place rocks it. I could eat it every day. Plus, the main waiter guy is SO funny! He seems to speak multiple languages and he's really good at guessing what you're going to order.

The only downside is that the location isn't the best, but I look past it for this pho!
author: Andrew H.

description:
Best Pho...ever.  

"Number Nine, no onions and cilantro."  

I've come to eat at this place so many times, the owner knows as soon as I walk in, what I am going to order.  Within literally 3 minutes, a piping hot bowl of delicious noodles topped with a generous portion of assorted tasty beef parts is presented to me.  

My pre-pho ritual is to put a bunch of bean sprouts into one corner of the bowl, then cover them with the clump of rice noodles inside, as to blanch them slightly.  I then slather on the sriracha and enjoy.  What sets this place apart?  Generous meat servings, delicious non-msg broth, and quick service.  I am salivating just thinking of this place.

I usually come to this place in the morning for breakfast, and am always treated to an exciting display of hookers, drug dealers, and users across the street.  Once I witnessed a police sting operation, cumulating in a knife fight across the street- all the while enjoying my delicious pho.  For authentic vietnamese noodles, you really have to go to the worst part of town in any city, and you'll find what you're looking for.  I was once even propositioned for sex by a 60 year old crack whore as I walked out of the restaurant, undoubtedly for my good looks and expertise in picking pho joints.

Getting your belly filled at 9am for $8 is priceless, and why I continue to make my way to this hole in the wall.
author: Eric K.

description:
The best place to get pho other than my dad's house.

and the vietnamese man there has the best memory of what you usually order. he never gets orders wrong by confirming that your #13 will come with steak and brisket. or your steak and brisket is #13.

best plus+++ 
the coconut juice is amazing for a hot day in the 'loin. 

the busy atmosphere, aroma, and hard viet languages among the viet contractors makes this place feel just like vietnam.
author: uly n.

description:
I love Pho -- especially when it's a cure for a hang over. The kind of hang over that lasts up until 4pm the next day because you were partying your ass off with vicadin and alchohal then puking your brains out. oh wait, this is a pho review...

Had the Pho Ga (which is chicken noodle soup for you non-vietnamese folks) -- it was good. Enough to cure me of my sickness. I would even come back again (as I anticipate more hang overs in the future). Better yet, this place is within my 4 block neighborhood radius. nice!
author: Vanessa J.

description:
Now be prepared for a lot of side comments:

Consider yourself warned.

I generally don't like eating in the tenderloin but when it's Sunday and everyone in Nob/Russian Hill  rushes to the Marina and you're sick, well gotta buckle down and into the heart of the ghetto. 
And I'm so happy I did. 
I'm high on flu medication and Rhapsody in Blue is playing on my iPod as I stroll past cracked out junkies, bums sleeping, random liquor stores, and lots of Indian restaurants I noticed (must check that out later.) 
I saw this place recommended on Yelp but it said it wasn't open on Sunday, boo. To my joyous surprise, it was and walking in and ordering take-out was too easy. 
There's a smattering of people here and there and this place seats a lot of people. At least 70. 
The lady behind the counter spouts out something in incoherent Englinamese? and reminds me of the Anjelah Johnson skit with the nail salon. 
'pick up a menu and being mildly surprised at the pleasant selection of brisket, balls, tripe, tendon, squid balls, chicken variations, I had to be that annoying person at the take-out counter hemming and hawing at her selection. 

Aw who am I kidding. Rare brisket with beef balls please.

Only $7. And she says to me, "3 minutes."

I thought I was still high on meds. "huh?" is my eloquent answer. 

She tolds up 3 fingers and says, "3 minutes."  Heh. Okay.

And lo and behold it was only 2 minutes 48 seconds! I was playing a game on my phone, okay? A man comes from out of the kitchen and hands me a white plastic bag neatly double wrapped and smiles. 

Take the package home and not expecting anything, (it WAS only 2 minutes and 28 seconds) I'm absolutely floored about how neat everything is packaged and how much food they give you. 
The basil, bean sprouts, lime, chili sauce, noodles, rare brisket is each packaged separately. Each in a little container or tiny bag and the rare brisket is practically frozen. In my past experiences, they usually toss everything in a bag and you'd have to go back time and time again for sauce, utensils, but not here. 
And now the taste test: d-e-l-i-c-i-o-u-s

The aroma of the basil and lime infused with the chili ladened beef broth open up those sinuses and I happily sniff and slurp my soup. I could only finish half and since they wrapped up everything so beautifully, let's call this a midnight snack! I won't judge a book by it's neighborhood anymore.
author: Jessica K.

description: I went to place over a year ago - was going to write a review, but couldn't remember the name of this place.  From what I remember, the pho was pretty good - the broth was very flavorful and they sure loaded up on the meat.  I believe prices were about average or slightly above average.  I wish I could say more, but I went there only once and a loooong time ago.  Will update if I head back there again.
author: Laura C.

description:
All pho was more or less the same until I tasted this place. My pho naivete was popped by you, Pho Hoa.

They have 5-10 different kinds of beef. All of superior quality.
author: Albie L.

description:
This a good place for Viet. food.  The food is tasty,  servings are pretty big, and priced fair.  Service is good too, with the main Vietnamese server dude always ready to take your order.  Very clean restroom too (amazing since it is located in the Loins/TL=Tenderloin).  As far as the location, it is not that bad.  Most of the time the local dweller's are too busy being in their own world or smoking crack rocks.  

FYI: if you don't want a front row seat seeing people smoking rocks out of a glass pipe, do not sit by the window.  ENJOY YOUR PHO!
author: ronzilla x.

description: Brought a pho virgin to this place. I know you're thinking that it must be an urban myth but yes they do exist. I promised him that I'd be gentle. But like all guys I've date, I lie Muahahahaha. I order us  two huge steaming bowl with all the fixings. He left satisfied. I on the other hand not so much.
author: Sophia C.

description:
Finding new pho restaurants in SF is a fun and interesting experience.   You never know what you're gonna get, especially when eating out in the Tenderloin.  Walking to the restaurant felt like meeting outcasts from  MJ's "Thriller" video.  People are a little bit crooked and quite undead.

Actually, most of the time you kinda know what to expect.  Broth, noodle, fresh herbs and bean sprouts etc. etc. But, certain restaurants have a tenacity to combine the ingredients in perfect harmony.

Pho Tan Hoa is really good and authentic.  They've got great Vietnamese karaoke music echoing from the background, sounding a bit spaghetti western mixed with old Yamaha keyboard tracks, and with a touch of reverb. Ah, reverb.

I recommend stopping in if you're in the neighborhood.  It's a yummy treat.
author: Hellyn M.

description: Went there for late lunch. They dont speak english.  Ordered soup when it arrived it had a bug in it. Never again. The owner was rude. We wanted to leave but he said that the other soup was fine only 1 had a bug. So we ended up paying him $10 for the other soup that wasn't touched. Soup didn't even cost $10.
author: Elena G.

description: Convenient locale, light speed service, more meat than noodles. No complaints. Bring cash.
author: JD M.

description: My friend Leland always orders the Beef Chowfun wet(with some sauce slobbered over it) and the Pho #1(with rare beef and stuff).  I thought it was pretty good.  Enough to share between the two of us.
author: Jim J.

description:
3.5 stars. so far, it has been the best pho ga i have had in town. it's getting close to the shops in San Jose. it is hard to get the broth for pho ga right and Pho Tan Hoa is almost there. the search continues but i will come back for sure. 

quick, cheap, pretty clean, lots of tables, ...oh, bonus points! they have satay [dried chili flakes in oil]!
author: Jocelyn T.

description:
Generous portions and reasonably priced.  Broth was beefy, which I like.  I understood about 30% of what the waiter said but he got our order right and that's all that mattered.

Worth a try!
author: Clayton K.

description:
I got #13 (beef pho with rare steak & meatballs) to go.  Their soup was delicious, as were their meatballs.  The rare steak was crazy.  It's the first time i've ever seen beef cut so thin.  literally, paper thin.  it cooked beautifully in my soup.

my only complaint is that they close so early.
author: H. L.

description:
One of the better bowls I've had so far in SF-- and I'm vietnamese and from san jose. The broth here is flavorful and with all the herbs this hits the spot you want a real (southern-style) bowl. 

Grilled pork chop, and che were just OK.
author: Amy D.

description:
Great...I see a guy getting ticketed for public drinking at 12pm just across the street from where i'm sitting. 
So glad our car is parked right where we can see it because i wnouldnt' be surprised  if some bum leaned against it begging for change. 
That is what makes tenderloin, The Loin.

Glad to have tried another authentic pho restaurant as the other place has been closed for 2 months! they must be in Vietnam. 
Pho tai is pretty good. Big Bowl. Good size dining area. Friendly.
author: Oanh N.

description:
Definitely the best Pho place by far in San Francisco. I ordered the "HOUSE" Special for $7.65 and you can easily share that with 2 people. The owners are pretty friendly also and it is really clean inside. My gf ordered the Halo Halo and enjoyed it along with the Vermicelli which I was able to share with her. I am so happy that I don't have to go all the way to San Jose now for good Pho.
Pho sho pho sheezy!!
author: Nir B.

description:
Pho Kho was good.  Broth on the side.  Chewy pho noodles (I will not eat brittle noodles).

Beef Pho was good too.

After leaving this restaurant, be prepared to smell like pho the rest of the day unless you shower and change.
author: HY L.

description:
The only downside to this place is that it closes too early - if you walk in at 6:45, this one guy will repeatedly remind/warn you that you only have 15 minutes to sit down, order, then eat.

The soup is always hot and the portions are humongous. They even put cilantro in the broth, which is becoming more rare these days...The fresh rolls usually come out after your soup, because (surprise!) they are made fresh! If you're close to Union Square or coming down the hill, come here for some good pho.
author: Jenny R.

description: What can I say? My parents used to take us here when we were younger and even though we moved to the other side of the city, it still hasn't stopped us from driving out there for a bowl of great tasting bowl of pho. The owners have known my parents for years. Seafood Noodle Soup pls!!.. Their combo noodle soups contains a lot of meat; something the men in our family love bc not a lot of pho places will do that. The kids enjoy their appetizers such as the egg rolls or fresh spring rolls. And for those of you who prefer rice to noodles, their rice plates are just as tasty and they're not stingy with their rice or meat so you won't be disappointed.
author: Anonymous P.

description:
This is actually the only pho restaurant I've eaten at, so I don't know how it compares to others.  But, I like it a lot.  There are a ton of different combinations, but I think it's best to keep it simple, with no more than 2 or 3 meats.  If you get more than that, you don't get enough of any one of the meats.  I like the rare steak and tripe best.  

Service is speedy -- less than 5 minutes between ordering and being served.  

The lemonade is really tasty, but the iced coffee is nothing special.
author: J S.

description:
I eat here about once or twice a month. The area can be sketchy but it's not as scary as others.

Service is usually very fast. Sometimes I think it's even faster than fast food! I pretty much only order 2 dishes here. The Nam Vang noodle soup (clear bean thread noodles with shrimp, fish cake, fish balls, lean pork & roast pork) and beef noodle soup with tripe and sliced beef on the side. These 2 are my absolute favorite dishes here. When the weather is too hot for hot soup, the cold noodle dishes are a good alternative. Also the fresh iced lemonade is awesome here. They mix it up when it's ordered so if you can wait till the end of your meal to drink it the flavors have time to "settle". The iced coffee is good too.
author: cyndi L.

description:
If you are brave enough or within the area....you should definitely try out this hidden pho place in the Tenderloin.  One of the original of the "three" pho places I've grown up with...i believe this is the only one still left standing.  Been going to this place ever since I was 5 years old and only thing that change is they added tapioca drinks to the menu.  

Their Pho Dac Biet (my favorite....my measuring stick) is top-notch and lets just say.....it's freaking HUGE.  Just make sure to ask them to heat up the bean sprouts and to put the rare beef on the side to make it more enjoyable. Pricing is reasonable and their broth is still pretty good for today's standard.  

Note to anyone brave enough to try this place for the first time......get a TL tour guide to bring you there

- Yummy for my tummmy
author: Dave L.

description:
is it me or did they raise their prices significantly?  a bowl of pho starting at $7.85?!?! holy crap.  there are places way cheaper and located in a much better neighborhood.

i ordered #50 - porkchop + shredded pork + fried egg over rice..
porkchop was pretty tough, and there was hardly any shredded pork.
author: JUDY L.

description:
Honestly most "Pho Hoa Hieps" are good
The one in Daly city , which is the third one and the 2nd in Irving is the best ! I went there for 6 years of my life and I am only 16, so thats a lot as you can see! Of course the Oakland Pho Hoa Hiep is good too, but kind of a grimy place.
 
I say this place is PHO-nominal!!!
author: Jimmy K.

description:
Pho Tai is great here.  There other menu items have been great in the past too.

Fresh soda lemonade makes me cream my pants...it's just lemon, sugar and soda water.  YUM  So refreshing on a hot day.

I recommend this place whole heartedly
author: Matt V.

description:
Overall- 4 Stars
This place is all about pho.  You can tell cuz you'll pass out from the yummy warm goodness well I hope so and not any MSG.

Local- 2 Stars
Usually I go to Little Saigon for my pho since the ones in SOMA just don't cut it.  However on my walk today I found this little jem - well thanks to Yelp who showed me the nearest Pho place to Union Square.  This place is definitely in the heart of TL though, but worth it if your looking for some serious pho but don't mind the parade of bums walking outside.

Space/Service - 3 Stars
You know the place is authentic when you go in and there's long tables that can sit 50 and the menu has like 100 different variations of pho (which is all the same except for like one or two ingredients.  I went right after work at the there were people eating which is a good sign, and the service was quick.

Food - 4 Stars
I got the small bowl which is pretty big.  The flavors were all there, I hardly had to drench it with hoisin and siracha sauce which is what I normally do.  Noodles were cook right, not to hard or soft.  Tendon and the rare flank were just right.  The brisket tasted differently, so not sure about that.  
With tax and tip my meal came out to over $10 bucks.  Hmm kind of pricey for pho, otherwise I would have givein it a 5
author: Manohak S.

description:
Haha, all you suckaz not willing to venture into the tenderloing are missing out on some good azz Pho!

The area really isn't that bad, especially if you go with someone during the day. The Pho restaurant is in the traditional format, something in between a sit down restaurant and a fast food store. You sit down at a table, but pay at the register at the end. Plus an old Vietnamese man takes your order hastily using the number system, so you know this place is authentic :)

There were many tables at this location (it was about the size of 1.5-2 starbucks) and it wasn't crowded at all on a Saturday afternoon.

My girlfriend and I both ordered the rare steak and flank combo, I got the medium ($7.50) and she got the small ($6.50). Small is more than adequate, and medium is plently large. Though if you are big guy and are hungry, I certainly recommend the medium (its only like a $1 more you cheap bastage :)

The Pho broth was quite good with the perfect amount of salt and great taste, but wasn't fatiguing to finish. Noodles and steak were tasty too. Not too much of a fan of the fatty flank, but I'll just pass on that next time. All in all I was very pleased, and hope to come here again....with a friend of course, cuz well, its in the Tenderloin and I'm a pansy (ok its not that bad at all peoples)
author: Varun ..

description: Excellent pho, quick and courteous service at this no-frills spot.
author: Joseph P.

description:
I live very close to this place and before this last time, the food and prices were good.  I ordered dinner to go and noticed the first thing, the prices had gone up, almost by over 30%.  But, worse, was the meal when I got home was lousy!  I ordered shrimp with vegetables and I swear there was little to no sauce on my order.  The shrimp and vegetables were at least fresh, but I don't like eating this type of food without sauce.  Also, the egg rolls were fair. Anyway, I trashed most of this and I will not go back.  The cheaper prices and good food were a hallmark of Pho Tan Hoa until this latest visit.  I don't know how they justify the higher prices with a decreasae in quality of food in this type of neighborhood.  

B.
author: Bernie B.

description:
Signs of a good pho joint:
More Vietnamese people than "other" people.
Questionable decor
Indifferent service.
Lastly, folks woofing down their food without all that talking business.
author: Andy L.

description: hola hola drink is good. But the Pho is just so so. Average at best, I had better.
author: Mike G.

description:
I went for brunch and I wanted to add to my bun list, yet I couldn't order the bun.  Not that they didn't have it (in very limited variety), and not that it didn't look good (the old lady across from me ate a big professional looking bowl with all the fixings), but when the pho smells that good and half the menu is devoted to it --- and a loud booming voice ricochets through my mind exclaiming  "Eat the Pho!" ...

I will do my duty in the eyes of the divine and pass this on "Eat the Pho!" ...

You shan't be disappointed.  Even the small pho, and I had pho tai, had more beef and more noodles in it then most other place's large --- including the excellent turtle tower.  The beef was good quality, very fresh and elementally beefy.  The noodles were perfect and the broth not over powering, but flavorful.

A fine bowl of soup for a Sunday morning.  So much better than going to Dottie's --- better food, and no one gave me curdled cream for my coffee and then blamed me for it.
author: Gustie L.

description:
We were going to another pho restaurant down the block, but it was closed for vacation.  As we already fed $3 worth of coins in to the parking meter for an hour and we were parked across the street from this place, we decided to try it instead of driving somewhere else.  What a pleasant surprise!  This is the CLEANEST Vietnamese restaurant I have ever been to in my 29 years in San Francisco, including much more expensive places.  The windows, the tables, the walls, the menus... everything was sparkling, Windex clean.  This is really WONDERFUL... especially in this sketchy Tenderloin neighborhood.

We ordered two bowls of pho and they were not bad.  The one with the rare steak and meatballs is quite good but the one with the chicken is just ok... there is not much chicken and even the little shreds of chicken were quite tough.  The service is friendly and efficient although they got my order wrong... I had ordered egg noodles  but ended up getting their regular rice noodles instead.  I decided that it wasn't a big deal and just ate that instead.  The prices are not cheap for that location... two "small"  bowls of pho came to $18 plus tip.
author: Eleanor C.

description: Hands down best pho in the city.  And amazing shrimp spring rolls.
author: julie w.

description: the best pho ever.... the portion is huge..the broth is the best ever...the price is very reasonable...and the service is great and fast......They have a large selection of food. However, the pho is the best..
author: Tiffany L.

description: Pho was good. Located in a bad neighborhood but its okay if you take a taxi to the restaurant before 5pm. Not a bad option if you are in the mood for Vietnamese food and are staying in the Union Square area during your visit to SFO.
author: Kim V.

description: I've been here more than a handful of times because my friend likes it but...eh, this place is okay -- if anything, I'd have to say it's a place I like to go to for "fast food" pho. I don't like it as much as Ha Nam Ninh which is just down the block. The broth here is flavorful but it's what I consider the "greasy" kind of pho. They allot nice portions of meat but the quality is marginal since some of it has more fat than I'd like. The service is what you'd expect it to be: your empty glass of water will probably not get noticed, but that's not to say the people who work here aren't nice. What I don't like about this place are the hours and the prices. They close pretty early (~7PM) and they charge more than they should for a mediocre bowl of pho.
author: Novi M.

description:
I've been searching for a place to be the yin to Turtle Tower's yang.  I love TT, but their soup is Hanoi style and I want me some Saigon style, too.  I was hoping this would be the place.  

I wasn't overly impressed.  And I've been to Vietnam, so I sort of know what I'm talking about.  I thought the broth was ok, but it had a chemical-ish undertaste.  

It was super clean in there, though.  And the service was nice.  Maybe I'd give it one more try?  I don't know...

The search continues...
author: jessica d.

description:
I always order the pho special with nuoc beo (bowl of liquid fat) and rare meat on the side (with a hot bowl of broth to further cook the meat without polluting my main bowl).  Decent broth, noodles, and meats.  Sometimes you'll get the bottom of the pot or weird cuts of meat but most of the time I'm satisfied.

Pho Tan Hoa gets four stars (based on a base of three stars) because I would regularly gather my beautiful co-workers for a pho trip from Downtown Financial in SF.  I do not factor the Tenderloin neighborhood into the rating.
author: Amanibhavam K.

description:
This is where I go for pho, mostly for proximity reasons.

Although Little Saigon is a few blocks away, and I totally could use the exercise, I always go here. I've gotten their rice plates a few times (and they're always delish), but the pho is what does it for me. The bowls are huge no matter what size you get, and the food comes maybe ten minutes after you've order it.

To be honest, I've only been to about ten different pho places in my life, and the majority of them pretty much taste the same. The only difference I notice is the combination and quantity of meats they include and the prices. (Maybe I put too much hoisin sauce to be able to tell the difference.)

I like this place because of the proximity, the prices, and the generous quantities of meat they give you with your order of pho.

The neighborhood is not that bad. The crackheads are totally dazed and in their own crack addled worlds. It may be depressing to look at, but you don't need to be packing heat to get by.

The seating arrangements make it a good place to bring a bunch of friends, but it might be awkward to go here for an intimate one-on-one meal if the restaurant is really packed (i.e. you may end up sitting next to strangers.)
author: Trish B.

description:
ooo--weee! kind of the best pho in san francisco so far. 

reasons why i love pho:
1) fast: at your table in about 5 minutes max
2) healthy-ish: its mostly fresh produce and very lean beef. the only downside is the risk of MSG. but judge-not lest you read the ingredients list on that sexy can of Swanson's broth lurking in your pantry. HA!!! not feeling so high and mighty now are you?
3) perfect for a hangover, an illness, or any sort of emotional ailment in which you feel the need to eat your feelings. 
4) cheap! 

contrary to any nasty rumors flying around, i'm a little sensitive about the things i'm willing to put in my mouth. I prefer things that don't look like they got coughed up by a very sick person, except muscles and clams. its not that i'd judge other's personal taste, its just that i have this gag thing that happens when i'm not fully onboard with what i'm about to eat. 

that being said I'm a little bitch about tripe and tendon and stick to plain old cow meat. if you're also  a little dodgy off that stuff i recommend getting rare beef, on the side of course. add your thai basil, chili peppers. lemon, and bean sprouts, slap in some hoisin and rooster sauce (sriracha) and commence binging. 

ok so i don't know if i have gotten any traditional method of eating pho down. i get a lot of weird stares people who actually know what the hell they are doing. ive developed a system of using the chop sticks with the right hand to lift and place the noodles into the big spoon with some broth, meat, basil, and slurp it down. the occasional noodle goes rogue and splashes pho broth in eye. i also slurp too hard sometimes, causing the soup to shoot to the back of my throat. since i like my broth really spicy at makes me choke and cough uncontrollably for a couple minutes. so yeah, i'm that one chick making a scene, losing her noodles, and generally struggling to down her medium bowl of pho in a reasonable amount of time. if you have any tips, please feel free to let me know. 



oh and about the location...
don't wander around the neighborhood expecting disneyland. yeah it sucks that it kinda smells just like pee throughout the TL, with scattered locations that smell just like poo. and sure a lot of the people are currently high out of their minds of drugs or plotting ways to be so in the immediate future. but im sure if you're reading this you're fortunate enough to have a life where you don't know what its like to be in the position where your best option is actually to pee on the street. these people would like some peace and dignity too. just don't loiter around like a jackass judging, be respectful of these people in their neighborhood, stick to your business, and you're fine.
author: Steph-a-saurus, Grr. J.

description: My standard pho joint.  The noodles are perfectly thin and chewy, the broth is delicious, and the meat is tender and flavorful.  Everything pho should be.
author: Carlin E.

description:
Best pho I've had in the city so far. All the right condiments on the table. Sure, sometimes you have a share a table, but that's part of the "atmosphere" of a dining establishment such as this.

On the whole, they provide clean, fast, friendly service. They even take bills larger than a $20 with a smile.

And I swear their broth has medicinal properties as well. I don't know what goes into it, but it sure does seem to kick a cold on its ass!
author: Buddha N.

description: GREAT Pho! Nothing snazzy about this place but the food is fantastic and the gentleman that runs the restaurant is very kind.
author: Elyse R.

description:
My first review and I'll give it 5 stars and to Pho Hoa!!!! Im Vietnamese so my comfort foods aren't mac and cheese nor pizza. It's Pho!!! I"ve been comig here since i was 5 years old. My father knows the owner because ofcourse all Vietnamese know each other....suppossedly...but im not being biased. They have the best pho and beef stew with bread and other things. They're specialty, i have to say, is their dried pho. best in town and noone makes it better. Its basically pho with no soup, well only on the side. Its the best ever!!!! Other resturants try to copy but needless to say, they did not succeed. 
  The soup base is the best and i would know. Theie portions are generous, so generous i always have to ask for less meat in my dried pho. The owner is so funny, i call him doublemmint guy because he always says everything double. "hello hello"! 
   The neighborhood is a bit sketchy but the if you eat here you will feel safe because i've seen them try to fight off guys who come in starting trouble with baseball bats!!!hahhahaha....
  Overall, i love this place!
author: Vi V.

description:
Always when i get back to San Francisco I try to find the better 'Pho' place. And after reading the comments about this place I decided to go there for breakfast. Early in the morning Tenderloin seems just to be another neighborhood with the typical amount of less fortuned people. But what else is new? We're in the States and Tenderloin seems to be one of the better 'bad' neighborhoods if you ask me.

Anyway, my GF and I fell immediately for the number 7, though she ordered the smaller one. Besides this I also ordered the 'Cafe sua da' translated as the Iced coffee with milk. Within less than 5 minutes the order arrived and the bowls were indeed huge! You can't get these kind of bowls anywhere in Europe (I'm from the Netherlands). And it tasted just GREAT! There was just no other better way to start my vacation in the States. My GF always wants the bean sprouts to be cooked and that wasn't a problem at all. The Basil leaves could have looked more fresh as there were some black spots on them. 

About the service, well it's definately not the American style. The waiter (or maybe the owner) is quick and knows his regulars and seems to be the only person who attempts to have a normal chat with a clear accent. The waitress seems not to have a lot of happy things going for her as there is not really a smile to be seen and doesn't really say much except for the amount that you have to pay at the register.

The bowl wasn't only big, the pho was filled full with steak, tripe etc. It tasted so good that my gf and I went back the next day. But I must say that the big bowl was a little too big for me and I know that my stomach is not small. The Pho served here is definately better than the Pho I had in Berkeley. 

BTW, the Pho served here is more the 'South Vietnamese' type of Pho that I prefer, unlike the 'Northern Vietnamese' type of Pho that they serve at the Turtle Tower.

I have been to Hawaii for the past 2 weeks and now I'm back in SF and just can't wait to get there again (like in 2,5 hours after writing this review).
author: Ha V.

description: I've been eating here for ages...Once you become a regular, the owner/waiter already reads your mind and announces your order to you to confirm.  The Pho soup broth is very authentic.  Pretty much everything on the menu is very tasty.  I recommend trying their special beef Pho soup with everything.  Just be cautious of your surroundings when visiting the neighborhood.
author: Jimmy N.

description:
As we make our one and a half block journey to Jones Street - I'm already displaying the sure-fire signs of Pho-Fever...I'm incoherent, have complete tunnel-vision, avoid making eye contact with all strangers, and my walk quickly becomes a trot.  One block to go and I'm already hallucinating of foliage... basil, saw leaves, cilantro, bean sprouts, scallions and chili envelop me.  I am delirious.  I am sweating.  I am so hungry I could eat the little Vietnamese guy that seems to live at Pho Hoa.  His voice resembles that of a 30 year old Vespa crossed with a lisping auctioneer.  I never know what the hell he's saying...but I don't care.  And like the finest of doctors - he immediately recognizes my symptoms, and within three minutes my liquid utopia is in front of me.  It's piping hot broth, full of flavor, has a wonderful depth to it.  I could just throw a sippy straw in the damn thing and go to town.  But first I must throw every damn bit of foliage lying around into it.  But this is where I stray from the mainstream.  I'll then gussy it up with hot sauce and Hoisin sauce.  A crime, I know.  I consider myself to be both hot AND sweet, and so naturally, I'd like my Pho to resemble me.  You are what you eat, after all.  

And damnit - we both taste Pho-nomenal.

My significant other generally does not order the Pho, substituting instead some sort of beef over rice concoction.  As delightful as his dish looks, I secretly think him a fool every time.  He always orders a fried egg atop his dish, and we are now three for three for his dish arriving egg-less.  He claims conspiracy.  I say that the good folks of Pho Hoa are simply looking out for his cholesterol levels.
author: Mc Matty b.

description: I really like their pho here - the broth is sooo tasty and the service is fast and the man that takes your order is so funny and oh so monotone in his voice. BUT the only thing that prevents me from coming here more often is where its located. SKEETCH. If you can get over the neighboorhood and run like a banchee into the safe haven of the restaurant then its all good. I've seen cops in here so it should be a pretty safe spot to eat at. I get the rare beef and beef ball pho and their spring rolls are fresh and tasty. Their small pho portion is huge! They give you a ton of meat with it.
author: Julie F.

description:
advice for those venturing to pho tan hoa:

hold your breath when you walk up jones street!  you think i'm kidding?!  ok, fine if you want your nostrils to smell like pee before you slurp  your pho.

watch where you're going when you walk down jones street!  you think i'm kidding?!  ok, fine if you want to be sprayed down with a waterhose by the guy who washes down the alley that smells like pee every afternoon before you slurp your pho.

order the shredded pork spring rolls!  you think i'm kidding?!  best spring rolls i've had in sf.  EVER.  really soft rice paper wrapping, good amounts of meat, and generous amounts of crispy lettuce and herbs.

expect the food to come out crazy fast!  with lots of meat and msg!  you think i'm kidding?!  we were in and out in 30 minutes, tongues tingly from MSG, with no idea of what to do with ourselves!  

one thing is for sure that when we left, we held our breaths and watched our steps walking down jones street!
author: Josie M.

description: Love love love this place minus the neighborhood. This place never lets me down whenever I crave for pho. Their soup is steaming hot and so delicious. Noodles are cooked perfectly and rare slices of beef are the right thickness so it's easy to chew.  My bf always orders his meat on the side and it costs and extra 50 cents.  but hey, they give you a separate small bowl of soup to cook your meat in so hes not complaining. Service is fast and efficient. One of the best pho restaurants in the city- hands down. Bun bo hue with small noodles is a must here! The broth is perfect-not too spicy and pact with tons of flavor. When you walk in, you are greeted by this stern looking man who loves to repeat "hello, hi hi" to every customer. Then, once you tell him your order, he would repeat everything that is included in your noodle soup. Sounds like he's mumbling in Vietnamese but I'm telling you, he is reading your order out loud.  Gotta love this place!
author: Irene L.

description: Pho Tai and ca phe sua da -- heaven. I went there about 1:30 p.m. on a Wednesday, got instantaneous service, a huge portion of red, luscious filet that cooked in 30 seconds in the sumptuous broth. Seems like there was only one size bowl on the menu ($7+), but really, I only glanced at it for a second because I knew I wanted Pho Tai. As others have noted, the owner is quite patient with English speakers. Very fresh basil and equally fresh bean sprouts. I will go back! By the way -- CASH ONLY.
author: Mindy M.

description: Everyone I have taken here who appreciates Pho agreeds it is unmatched in SF.  Cash only, low cost, generous portions of "the good stuff", heavy beef broth, optional raw beef on the side.  Served with lemon, bring your own lime or buy one at a shop across the.street.  This is the place locals know to go for Pho.
author: Sean M.

description: On a trip to San Francisco was searching for a place to get authentic pho.  I'd heard to steer clear of the Tenderloin, but I figured it couldn't be worse than what I've encountered in NYC.  Walking into Pho Tan Hoa, I knew right away I was in for something good.  It's a no frills type place, and not touristy at all.  The pho broth was really good, and a 'small' bowl was more than I could finish...very good portion of meat for what I paid.
author: Kristen P.

description: Good pho. The dry pho is quite different and quite good.  No complaints.
author: Mai H.

description: While not quite as good as the pho place in the 99 Ranch plaza in Richmond, the pho here is pretty damn good.  I am not a very religious person, but I am here almost every Sunday praying to the pho gods that reside this lovely little spot on Jones and O'Farrell.
author: Julie H.

description: Definitely the best beef pho I've had in the city. The small bowl is just the right amount. If you're starving, get the XL (Xe Lua) bowl. It's HUGE. Very quick and efficient service.
author: Trinh T.

description:
After reading the Yelp reviews, and since this place was practically around the corner from my work, I decided to brave it and try it out, even though it's venturing more into the Tenderloin than I like to go. I was in a rush, so I couldn't eat there, but wanted to bring it back to my desk. I asked the fella how much time it would take to make Pho to go, and he said "four minutes" -- which seemed surprisingly fast, and also surprisingly specific for a waiter at a venue like that. I looked through the menu, chose #20: the chicken version (sans the in-shell baby eggs) and sat down at an empty table to wait. While I was sitting there, I perused the menu in more depth, when suddenly my water surprised me with a bag of my food! I mean really... it couldn't possibly have been four minutes. I'd say three max. Probably less. 

I was delighted and paid my $6.75, and went back to my desk at work, where I proceeded to pull out the big assortment of items in the bag: a huge styrofoam bowl of broth, a plastic bag of flavoring items: fresh cilantro and basil, sliced jalapeno, fresh lemon, and a little dish of flavored sauce. Then there was a paper box full of the fixin's for the Pho: strips of fresh cooked chicken and bean sprouts. I'm pretty sure I'm forgetting a couple of other ingredients too, but that's the basics. They included a fork, spoon, chopsticks and a bunch of napkins -- and I used them all! I added the ingredients in the proportions that I wanted, and I tell you -- IT WAS SO DELICIOUS! The broth itself had a wonderful taste, and the ingredients were so fresh. Nothing was wilted or unpleasant in any way.  And it was a huge amount for lunch. Two people could easily split this -- which qualifies the place with that extra-special quality that I love so much: cheap-eats!

Next time I'm going to eat there in the restaurant, because although it was delicious at work, the hand-mixing of an assortment of ingredients is not conducive to a paper-strewn desk. The inside of the restaurant didn't look too bad (although really, I wasn't there long enough to get much of an impression!) -- but it was your standard low-budget formica and florescent lights, and I'm just going to cross my fingers that the condiments and walls and stuff look clean when examined up close. (I will completely write off a dirty/greasy-looking restaurant, no matter how delicious their food is.)

Before this week, my hands-down favorite big-but-budget soup in town was Chava's (see my review), however this place now has earned position right up beside by beloved Chava's chicken soup.
author: Zoe H.

description:
It's time to show this place some love.  I literally eat here three times a week, it is that good.  The older guy, (maybe the owner?), knows me and my food is always so quick and very very hot.  I never have the patience to wait for my pho, and 80% of the time I burn my tongue. SO sad... 

So I started out just ordering the pho ga, because I was a novice and chicken noodle soup is safe, but the rare beef and beef ball pho is really really good ( I order the beef on the side and they bring you an extra broth to cook the meat in, its kinda fun and then it doesn't get over cooked in your boiling hot soup).  They have a seafood pho that is not my favorite, but good.  And my friend tried a noodle plate of chow fun with mix veggies and shrimp that was spiced really nice.  

When I go, its always for the beef or chicken pho, lots of sprouts, basil and peppers, sriacha and a little hoisin.  Turtle Tower can eat it cause Pho Tan Hoa is king!
author: Jaylene S.

description: Just got pho, place was ok--typical vietnamese pho place.
author: Jung-Ah Y.

description: I'm updating because I have basically been coming here once a week. $8.25 for a large bowl of pho (#11) that feeds both me and my bf. Plus, the owner guy has never given us dirty looks for ordering one thing for two people. The broth is delicious!! Soooo yummy!
author: Angela L.

description: I liked the pho here although I did find a better bowl down the street (won't name names here).  The whole setup/community table thing is great, the guy running the place is friendly and, as stated, the pho is good.  Definitely worth a try.
author: Randy G.

description: Everyone knows I love to PHO!!!  This is hands down the best of the best broths I've ever had...It's in the hood tho (i have to spell tho like that to make it sound more hood).  You may have to pay a streetwalker (pimp, bum, hooks) to watch your ride, but it's worth it.  They have the best Pho Tai, Pho Ga, Pho Anything and there's a surprise in the bowl for all you garlic lovers.  Come one come all...bring change for the meters and the street walkers.  Keep on PHOing...it's good for you.
author: Deborah V.

description:
In my opinion, there's only one way to judge a vietnamese place: pho tai.

Sure, there can be other good dishes, as there are here (grilled beef bun), but if the broth on a beef pho can't bring it, find another place.

So this is subjective, but i say too salty, meat is too rubbery, and noodles taste stale.

With all the great pho options in SF, don't spend the time and money here.
author: jason e.

description: Their prices has went up a lot over the years. I mean come on, $9 for Pho? I thought pho was one of those grimey hole in the wall establishments that you go to for a quick and cheap meal. This spot is legit for their dry pho though. I don't recall their regular pho but I only come here for their dry pho. No it isn't just separating the noodles with the beef. It's more than that. It's how the noodles stay chewy and not expanded and soggy at the end from the broth. It's also the sesame oil (I think) that they drizzle in the noodles that you don't get if you order the regular pho. I used to wonder why they serve two bowls of broth with the dry pho, but I recently was told that if you opt for your beef served on the side, which I do, they give you one bowl of broth to eat your noodles with and another PIPING hot bowl for you just to cook your rare beef in. AND since I'm hella asian I automatically think that's a plus for an extra bowl of soup eventhough I'm not even going to finish the first. Maybe one of these days I'll have the courage to try something new here, in the meantime, I'll keep coming back for their dry pho.
author: Elaine L.

description: This might very well be the best pho in the city. Beef quality is excellent, noodles are fresh and chewy and the broth is outstanding, which as any pho lover knows is the foundation of good pho. Try the iced coffee. Spring rolls are only average. Just don't go expecting amazing service - this is like a lot of Asian places - good, fast, cheap food but relatively low on service. Go if you want fantastic pho!
author: J H.

description: Went here today and had one of the best ph I've ever had, beside the one in San Jose. I ordered the #7, and wow that bowl was huge! I can see why they charge $7 for it. Comes with tons of meat and noodles and well. The Soup is perfect, the flavor was awesome. The service was fast and everything was fresh and the restaurant was pretty clean from what i saw. I would give this place 5 stars, but the environment outside isn't all too safe.. haha
author: Brian P.

description: My expectations of this place was very high.  My co-workers (who pronounce Pho as "fow") spoke highly of this place, saying it's the best Pho in the city.  I ordered their combination Pho with all the fixings and it was exactly as described... really good.  Everything to the last slurp was very enjoyable.  The service was fast and straight to the point.  Don't expect these guys to strike up a conversation with you.  Prices are reasonable.   Parking is pretty scarce, but if you find yourself in this part of town be sure to pay this spot a visit.
author: R B.

description: Without a doubt the best tasting Pho in SF.  Try the sliced rare beef soup and be transported directly to brothy heaven.  Bonus points awarded for the free "street theater" (i.e., crack seeking and/or enjoying behavior) playing nightly out the front window.  Become a "regular" and the owner / host (who has the most unique voice) will make a game out of remembering your order.  This spot is tops.
author: A H.

description: I got the pho dac biet. It was only OKAY and edible. The broth was a bit bland and the bowl of pho was pretty expensive for pho. Pho Hoa Hung in Oakland and Pho #1 in san jose is ALOT better. I'm not going to come back here to pay alot of OKAY pho.
author: Beach L.

description: The Pho was very good. I usually just get the rare steak and the well done Beef, which is what I ordered here, but the numbers on the menu did not match the numbers in the servers head.  He did repeat the order back but to be honest I couldn't understand him so I picked out the tripe and tendon from my meal once it came.  The food was good, the price was right and the service was fast.  I would recommended parking and walking here as when we came out there was a bum party happening on our car, parked around the block.
author: Jerad D.

description: Located in a scary area but the pho was worth it. Rare steak was very rare but cooked quickly in the soup. Fast service.
author: Angela K.

description: Other than the location The place is probably the best in san francisco. Good price for alot of pho! good pho and prettty good service! Highly recommended.. Only bad thing is they only take cash..
author: d n.

description: pho was very good...halfway through a bowl and i hear something...hmmm..whag can it be? whoa! it's an employee/possible owner clipping his finger nails behind the counter! haha! at least it wasn't in the kitchen...pho was really good! just wondering what lies at the botyom of my bowl!?
author: christopher w.

description:
The pho here is tasty. The broth is really clean (not cloudy), and the noodles are cooked just right.

4 stars in my book.

Be sure to bring cash. There is an ATM box just outside the front door, but it hits you with a $2.75 fee.
author: Rich C.

description: i have been coming here for a very long time. if i was to give a review a year back it would have been easily a 4 star rating. As of lately i went back i noticed the pho here is starting to suck.  The noodles are way undercooked now and it seems like when i want eat its either hit or miss on certain days. i just hope that the consistancy will go back like it was before.
author: Art N.

description:
A good, go-to pho place smack in the middle of the city, for you folks who don't wanna hike over to Richmond/Sunset area for good Asian food.

Walked in for a Saturday lunch around noon, by myself. Wasn't too crowded, the service was prompt, and the pho came out steaming hot. The broth was mild and clean-tasting, although I would prefer it to be more flavorful. But I refrained from using any sauce (for I don't believe any broth-based noodle dish should be enjoyed with additional flavor other than what it comes with). The portion was big, enough noodle and meat. The noodle was very soft and almost, I'd say, starchy, which is not a bad thing for me. The beef, however, wasn't the best-quality meat that you can get at a pho place. As a matter of fact, one of the beef (I would guess skirt steak or something similar) was a bit smelly, but tasted fine. It made me think about it a lot though the whole time I was there. But anywho, the overall experience was good. They only take cash, which some people fie upon, but I don't really care if they don't want to give the credit card companies any money. Besides, it is almost customary nowadays to expect a joint only to take cash if it's either in a shady neighborhood or a cheap, ethnic place run by people with less-than-perfect English, right?

This will be a go-to place for me whenever I crave for pho when I'm at home. I just hope that none of the beef will smell next time. Please don't. I want to like you.

(Note: I care about pho places a lot for some reason, so hence the extensive write-up.)
author: Inbae L.

description: This is the best Pho restaurant in San Francisco. It is not the best, but it is pretty close. Guys should get Number 7 (menus changed recently) and girls should get Pho Tai number 13. The raw meat salad is also good.
author: Dao C.

description: This is five stars for SF. If I were comparing it to the east coast experience it's only four stars. I would recommend this place to anyone who wants a hot steamy bowl of yummy goodness. Its true that you should only eat pho in the places where it's in the name. But things other than pho are good here too! Like the Bun Thit Nuong Cha Gio (verm w/ grilled pork and egg rolls) is overflowing with noodles and toppings, including veggies. What's best is the waiter. He defies the stereotype I was talking about in my last po pho phiasco. He shouts recommendations while peeking over your shoulder: "#12, 13, 30!"
author: Kim G.

description: Yummy! Pho Tan Hoa makes one of the best buns I've had in SF. They have a huge menu too, I'll definitely be back for more dishes! One of my main complaints about Vietnamese in SF is that most restaurants have a fairly small and somewhat specialized selection. Not so with Pho Tan Hoa! Everything you hear about the "auction" guy is true too, he talks a mile a minute and repeats your order exactly =) I definitely recommend this place!
author: Will A.

description: got the combination seafood and egg noodle pho.  it tasted good, eggrolls were standard fare.  The pho wasn't amazing, but definately good.  Wish that had more selection of pho without tripe...i see people talking about create your own pho, but i tend to stick to the menu at these type of places as communication as a pale white boy doesn't always seem to work that well.
author: Brett T.

description: Been here twice recently. Had BBQ chicken with vermicelli, very nice, gotta mix lavorful chicken with bland-as-hell noodles, but good. Had chicken pho second time, excellent, they let you mix in what you want. Tip: really good with vast quantities of lime juice and green chili peppers soaking in the broth. Yum! Pho a bit salty, tad oily, still great!
author: Ben B.

description: The aroma of 'pho' in this restaurant always gets me all the time.  Sometimes I don't plan to eat pho, but this aroma makes me order it everytime.  To me, this is the best pho place in San Francisco so far.  I have tried so many places and no where around in the San Francisco Bay Area can beat this place.  Make sure you ask for 'ngo gai' (the green minty vegie) as well, they never offer it unless you ask for it.  Also the vinegar white onion is awesome and worth asking for.
author: Lily K.

description: So many pho places to choose from in SF, but this one's my favorite. Fast and cheap, and the house special is just filled to the brim with beef in all its glory. If you're a tendon fan, this is the place to go. Unfortunately it's tucked away on one of the Tenderloin's more unsavory streets.
author: Calvin L.

description:
3.5
i like the waiter (owner?) who talks like an auctioneer with a heavy accent.
broth is pretty good but a little intense for me.
portions are generous and come with very thinly sliced rare beef (if you order one of those phos)... i almost wish it weren't so thinly sliced bc it cooks a little too quickly and is all chewy a few minutes into the bowl
standard fixin's, but sprouts could stand to be less... wet?
fluorescent lighting, no ambience. most of the customers are asian locals, always a good sign.
the pho would be just right if not for the too-something broth (salty? msg-filled? it made me super thirsty)
author: Dana D.

description:
It's true what they say about this place ... there's so much MSG in the broth that it'll make your tongue mad at you for several hours afterwards like you smoked 10 cigarettes at once... and the noodles clump ... what's up with that? 

But, the pho is pretty decent, the service is good, and the bathrooms are so damn clean -- ahh if that was only the case for the surrounding neighborhood. And I complain not because I'm someone from Orinda or something unaccustomed to the loin ... I only live about 10 blocks away.

Eating here sadly reminds me of how much I miss Hung Ky though. Why did they have to close?? ;( 

Maybe it was one too many broken windows or angry homeless people peeing outside the window. Free range beef pho with delicate star anise flavor and unclumpy noodles for 5 bucks ... i'd gladly wade through pee for it. The people at Hung Ky were nice too. 

Pho Tan Hoa is good but it reminds me of how much I miss my other favorite southern style place. But it's a good hold over until I can find another favorite spot that's not an hour away.
author: j. d.

description: I like Pho.  The Pho here was really good. There were some extremely obnoxious loud fat Americans sitting in front of me yelling at the waitress...which kind of spoiled my nice quiet bowl of soup.  But I doubt they go all of the time, so don't let this deter you. And yes, you will have to walk down the seedy crack filled streets of the TL. WATCH OUT.
author: Rikki D.

description:
I'm giving this place five stars because every time I come here, I get the same good PHO.  My husband is a die hard PHO fan and we go to different places around the city to survey Pho.  This place is the real thing.  Soup is flavorful, meat is always fresh and if you order beef on the side, they'll give you an extra bowl of steaming hot soup to cook it in.  The portions are perfect and they always give you just enough noodles with the right amount of tendon, tripe and other good stuff.  The beef meatballs taste good, not rubbery like the other places.  Noodles are of perfect consistency, not too soft and not too chewy.
Service...A trip!  You can always expect the same Vietnamese guy with an accent to greet you.  He talks so fast that it takes a little while to understand what he's saying. At first you might think he is rushing you or being a bit rude, but no, if you've come here as much as we have, you'll realize that he just talks really really fast.  He always says thank you when you leave.  
Seriously, when my hubby and I crave a bowl of Pho we come here despite a 30 mile drive to the Tenderloin in a pretty seedy neighborhood.

You can't be a wimp if you want a real bowl of pho...get down to Cracktown and have yourself a PHO DAC BIET with Beef on the side at Pho Tan Hoa.
author: Kerry L.

description: The Pho Ga is really authentic and more flavorful than a lot of other places in the Bay Area. (Even places I consider very good.) I took our 4 year old and our 1.5 year old and both of them gulped down the broth like it was going out of style.
author: Marc E.

description: This is by far my favorite pho spot in SF!  The Pho Tai is tasty, the meat is consistently amazing.  I am getting hungry writing this...
author: Alejandra N.

description:
This the best Pho place in the city.  Simple as that.

The neighborhood is fine you wusses, I live across the street from this place and seriously, elderly asian women walk around here all the time and if they can handle themselves so can you.
author: John Paul M.

description:
The service is good, but the pho there isn't what I'm looking for. I like when there are fresh veggies (not black spotted basil), and clear broth (that isn't fatty). I personally thought that the pho was pricey for what it was. 

On a good note however, they had clean chopsticks, spoons, and sauce bowls. Their bean sprouts were fresh and the rare slices of steak were of good quality.
author: Shohty G.

description: This is by far the best place to eat PHO! not chicken noodle, or anything, PHO! All the meat is tender and fresh and when you get it on the side, its even better! If you want to eat a good and inexpensive lunch, this is the place to go! Quick and filling, and the food tastes great!
author: Q W.

description: the only place i go to for dry pho.  haven't really really tried anything else.  pretty bomb diggity tho.  you might want to wear some ear plugs as the main guy who takes your order is really loud.
author: Domino P.

description: This place is my second favorite Pho restaurant in SF, it would of been my first if it wasnt for the location it was located at. Every thing about this restaurant is just right, from the yelling owner asking you what you want to eat to the large portions that are being served. mmm mmm mmm just love this place. I especially love the fact that they give you a extra bowl of soup when you order your rare steak on the side (separated from your soup), i mean dont get me wrong i love me some blood infuse in my soup but the extra soup just makes it better. Just an all around great place to get your pho craving satisfied. Dac Biet FTW!
author: Win L.

description: This is my favorite Pho spot. The broth is perfect, just the way I like it. The service is quick, and I never have to tell them what I'm having. I'm a regular here you see. I've been living in the Tenderloin for 17 years now, and come here to eat Pho atleast once a week. It's like therapy for me. Just a time to unwind and sit down and enjoy a nice bowl of Pho.
author: KHiet H.

description: I went here when I was a kid when this place was owned by a different owner and I still come here almost every weekend. Always greeted by "Mr. Hello Hi", "look menu, I come now". The food is almost with plenty of meat and good broth in the pho. The Bun vermicelli and bbq pork/beef is usually a good alternative. But I have noticed the prices are getting pretty expensive, but if the quality is kept the extra cash wouldn't be a problem.
author: Lawrence L.

description: I don't pretend to be an expert on pho.  I haven't been to Vietnam, or dated a Vietnamese person, or read books about pho.  All I know are my taste buds and DAMN, I love this place.
